dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hot summer day in downtown LA. The streets are crowded traffic, dubious street vendors and preachers loudly proclaiming the Apocalypse. The mostly Hispanic crowd mix with tourists, who stare at this unfamiliar spectacle. BILLY BRODY, early twenties, a street-smart hustler, atte to cross the street. Billy’s basically a nice guy, despit having walked down some mean streets.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STANLEY'S KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: The place, a true “hole in the wall” hasn’t seen a new pi of furniture since the day it opened. The big blue “C” fo cleanliness prominently displayed, fits. A few locals contemplate their lives over coffee as the air-conditioni hums away. Billy slides onto a stool at the counter. The waitress, SARAH, a beautiful young woman in her late teens, comes out of the kitchen carrying plates of food. Sarah smiles at an older man sitting at the end of the counter while sliding a plate in front of him, then swerv to deposit the others. She glides toward Billy. The two k each other. There is an obvious attraction.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Hi. What can I get you? Billy stares and smiles as Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Well, I was thinking about the... Sarah starts writing.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: ...Turkey-sandwich? She winks at him. Billy’s delighted she knows it by heart

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just guessing. Sarah sticks the order on the ticket spindle behind her a moves to a soda dispenser, filling a glass and puts it in front of Billy.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Diet coke?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: That’s right. How’s everything? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just another slow day. Anything else I can get you? Billy hesitates. Something is on his mind.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: No, not really. Thanks. Sarah is about to walk away. He calls to her.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was wondering...

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Yes? There is an awkward pause. Then:

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: It’s been weeks now, me showing up here, eating my turkey sandwich...

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I was thinking: What if I show up here like tomorrow and you’re no longer here?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I guess I’m somewhere else. My day off. Like I should be so lucky.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean that.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Why wouldn’t I be here?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You could like decide to get another job, or somebody gets sick at home and you'd have to leave. Anything can happen, you know.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Well, I wasn’t planning to spent the rest of my life in this place.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You see? That’s my point. Suppose you left with me never finding out your favorite ice cream, your favorite movie, if you like pizza over hamburgers -..stuff like that...or-- Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --I prefer burgers to pizza, my favorite movie’s Fight Club, and my favorite ice cream’s pistachio--

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You wanna go out with me sometime? I got Dodger’s tickets this Saturday. Wanna go? Sarah is charmed. Billy smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Let me think about it.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I knew it. You don’t like baseball.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S8.)
dialogues.text: Sarah! Sarah turns and sees her BOSS, a heavy-set man in his fifties, waiving his fingers toward her.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I gotta go. Billy, disappointed, looks on as Sarah disappears into th kitchen. He peeks into the kitchen, catching glimpses of Sarah, as she argues with her boss. Billy sighs. Bad timi He leaves a ten-dollar note on the counter, then strolls a sign saying “Thank you, have a nice day”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy exits the elevator of a parking-structure with his phone pressed to his ear while walking along rows of park cars toward a beat-up, sixties, yellow convertible.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: It's Billy. Billy keeps Stanley’s Kitchen on the opposite side of the street, in view. He spots Sarah, still in her waitress uniform, exiting Stanley’s Kitchen. She pulls out a cigar and lights up. BILLY (CONT’D) Gotta call you back.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: What the f...?!! Billy starts rushing toward the staircase as he flips his phone closed. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aggravated and confused, Sarah is pacing in front of Stanley’s. Billy approaches without her noticing.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Hey! Sarah turns, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Oh, hi.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I saw you coming out. (beat) We never finished our conversation about-- He sees there’s something the matter.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You must be a psychic. Remember you said what if you came by tomorrow and I wouldn’t be here. Well, guess what? Stanley’s is closing. I’m out of a job. They stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I don’t know what to say. I’m really sorry. Hey, it might be a blessing in disguise. Maybe better things are waiting to happen for you.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I sure hope so. I got bills and rent due.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Is there anything I can do? The front door of Stanley’s opens. Sarah’s Boss calls.

dialogues.speaker: OWNER
dialogues.text: Sarah, you wanna finish your shift?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I’m coming. Her boss's face disappears as quickly as it popped up.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anyway, not a good day. Sarah turns to leave. Billy calls out again. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don’t I give you my number. You know, just in case, you feel like calling.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Ook. Billy quickly pulls out an old receipt, but struggles to a pen. Sarah chuckles, then pulls out her pen.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Thanks. He scribbles down his name and number, hands the paper ba to her. Sarah looks at it, brightens.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Funny. I didn’t even know your name. Billy. I like it. She turns to leave. He calls out to her.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Your pen! Smiling, she spins around, picks her pen from his fingers Sparks are flying.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Thanks. See ya later, Billy. Billy watches Sarah slip inside, a big smile on his face. INT. BILLY’S MOTEL ROOM, NIGHT A dark, cheap bedroom. Billy is asleep in his clothes. Th telephone rings persistently. Billy, sleepily, reaches ou the phone on his night table.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Yeah? Hello? A look of alarm comes over him. BILLY (CONT’D) Sit tight. I’m on my way. He falls out of the bed, fumbles for car keys, throws on jacket and exits the room. It sits empty for a few seconds before the phone starts t ring again, insistent and ominous.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREETS, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dark and empty, barely illuminated, ignored neighborhoods CU: SPINNING WHEEL of Billy’s convertible, top closed. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Billy steers the car over the rough pavement, old train tracks of downtown LA. An occasional neon flashes by. He squeezes the steering-wheel and keeps flooring the pedal the old V8 roars at hair-raising speed. EXT. SARAH’S APARTMENT BUILDING - EAST LA, NIGHT The convertible comes to a screeching halt in front of an apartment building. Billy jumps out of the car, quickly m his way through the front door of the dilapidated buildin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy runs up the staircase facing a gloomy, long hallway walks down the corridor, checking for the right apartment From an apartment door at the far end of the hallway, a d figure watches Billy who momentarily senses it: He quickl turns and peeks down the corridor: Nothing. Puzzled he mo on. Suddenly, a loud BANG as a door is slammed shut. Bill whirls around. Again. Nothing. Billy finds his way to the correct apartment. He takes a breath, knocks.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Sarah? It’s me, Billy. Open up! No answer. He turns the knob.

dialogues.speaker: INT. APARTMENT, NIGHT
dialogues.text: A true dump: Dim light, trash everywhere, cheap furniture Dirty, yellow walls show cracks, dubious spills. Drug paraphernalia spread out on a coffee table. The twisted and lifeless body of a girl is spread out on nearby sofa. As Billy slowly enters he freezes at the sight of the dea girl, syringe still sticking in her arm. His face drops a moves closer toward the dead girl: Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (a horrified whisper) Shit! Sarah! Suddenly Billy’s jolted by the sound of a faint sob. He t and recognizes a familiar silhouette which gives hima moment's relief: It’s Sarah. The resemblance between the girl and her is striking.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sarah...what is going on here? Sarah is tear-stained, traumatized.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Ellen, she...I...I...couldn’t..she-- Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Sarah. Suddenly, police-sirens can be heard in the distance. Bil grabs Sarah by the arm. BILLY (CONT’D) C’mon grab your stuff...Now! A series of JUMP CUTS Billy helping Sarah dress/Billy stuffing clothing and oth random belongings into an old duffel-bag/Sarah rapidly st pictures, mail, a few stray folders in a garbage bag. Bil taking a last look at the corpse as the two make a rapid exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Customers sit at the counter of a retro-style coffeeshop. Billy sips a soda in a secluded booth towards the back. Returning from the bathroom, Sarah slides into the booth. She is red-eyed from hard crying and still dazed.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You're ok? Have some coffee, a muffin. You’1l feel better. He points to the coffee and an English muffin in front of her. Sarah glances at Billy nervously.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I suppose I owe you an explanation. It’s fucked up...how life can turn on you so god damn quick. Just yesterday I was full of hope, things were changing for the better. Finally. Next thing I know I’m out of a job, hours later I find my best friend with a needle in her arm. Dead. For a moment, it looks like she’s going to lose it.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Take it easy.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: The girl...is...was...Ellen. My roommate. Billy nods, trying not to pressure her.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, you've figured out by now I’m not this sweet, innocent girl you probably might’ve thought I was... A couple of moments pass. Sarah removes her jacket and stretches out her bare arms. She turns both her arms, revealing numerous scars. Needle marks. Healed up. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That’s the past. I don’t do that anymore.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Okay. Quietly, she continues.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: A few months ago, Ellen said she'd had enough of all this drug bullshit. She wanted to go back to school. So, she decides we should both check into rehab. She’s on the phone for days till she Manages to find a place that takes us. She even paid for it. So, we got really stoned and we went to this clinic. Except when I woke up, she was gone. I stayed.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What happened to her?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: They woke her in the middle of the night. Her parents had died in a car crash the day before we checked in.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Wow. That’s really fucked up.(pause) What about tonight?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: We got into a fight because I asked her not to get loaded around me. I tell her I’m trying to stay clean and seeing her get high doesn’t make it any easier. I don’t think any of it registered, y’know? Couple of hours later I hear her fighting with the guy from next door, her dealer. Our dealer. At some point I fell asleep. Sarah winces at the memory, starts to tremble.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And then I just woke up, for no reason, y'know, how that happens sometimes? And I see her on the couch sleeping...only she isn’t making noises, like she’s breathing... She starts to sob quietly, again. She puts her forehead between her hands. Billy gently touches her wrist.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If only I’d just gone next door and told that prick to leave us alone! Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thing is, if it wouldn’t have been that dealer, she’d have gotten her dope someplace else. If this didn’t happen last night maybe it would have happened today. Some people just have a short ticket on this planet. There’s no rhyme or reason for it. It just is. Sarah stares at Billy. She pulls out a cigarette, nervous plays with it. Then:

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What am I doing laying all this shit on you. We don’t even know each other.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: We sort of do now, don’t you think? Sarah sighs, glances far away.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I should go to the police.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Why? Won’t make any difference now. It’s nobody’s fault.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What am I going to do? I don’t even know where I’m going to stay.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: How about your folks? Where’s home?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Wisconsin? No thanks. Not interested.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You can stay with me if you like.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MOTEL ROOM, NIGHT
dialogues.text: The door opens with Billy and Sarah locking lips ina passionate kiss. Billy kicks the door shut...

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Sarah and Billy are making love face to face.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MOTEL ROOM, DAY
dialogues.text: It’s the next morning. CU: SHOWER HEAD. Water pours down on Sarah’s face.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  10.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MOTEL ROOM, DAY
dialogues.text: Leaning against the railing of the second floor, Billy, c phone to his ear, overlooks the old swimming pool of the fifty plus room motel. In jeans and T-shirt, Sarah steps through the open door. Billy turns, closes up his cell ph

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Look. Thanks for getting me out of there last night. That was really cool, but I totally don’t want to take advantage of you. I should probably go and sort out my own problems... Billy interrupts gently.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: +..you can stay as long as you like. She studies him for a beat. Gives a searching look.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You don’t think I’m trash?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (shrugs, shakes his head) I do not. Everybody’s got a story, a bad thing that happened. My theory on life is ‘what happened, happened’. It’s what you do here and now and tomorrow that counts. Sarah permits herself a smile.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Okay then Mr. Glass Half Full. How about you? Like I know nothing about you. Why are you living in a motel?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Ahh, it’s temporary. I’m waiting for my brother to come back from overseas. He’s setting up shop in LA, pending how it goes with his suppliers. Wants me as his right-hand man.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What kind of business?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Import-Export. That kind of thing. Sarah smiles. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  11.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Well, I know you’re from Vegas, your Mom owns a wedding chapel....you told me that the first time you were at Stanley’s.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You know more about me than most. Sarah gets a far-away rueful look in her eye.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I haven’t been to a ball park since I was five. That would've been really nice. Billy moves in and gently kisses Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: So, you do like baseball after all.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I love it.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Billy, spread out on the king size bed, watches baseball TV, while Sarah rummages through her duffel-bag. However, instead of socks she pulls out several envelopes.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: This is not my stuff. Perplexed, she drops into a nearby chair, pulls out a let from an already open envelope.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got some of Ellen’s mail by mistake. Sarah starts reading out loud.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Law offices of Cameron Brogden, State of Alabama. January 15th...Dear Ellen. As your late uncle’s friend and attorney, your uncle has bequeathed his entire estate to you, his favorite nice and the only living relative... I didn’t even know she had an uncle... Billy looks up, looks at Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --. however, please be informed that under Alabama law I have filed in probate court... you know what this is? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  12. She throws the letter onto the bed. Billy picks up the pi of paper and continues reading the text.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (reading out loud) +... please be informed that under Alabama law I have filed in probate court... a process that might take up to ninety days. If you have any questions please contact me at your convenience, signed Cameron Brogden, attorney at law... maybe we should contact this lawyer. What else in the bag? Once again Sarah digs through the bag’s content. Suddenly she holds up a wallet. Billy moves closer. BILLY (CONT’D) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: It’s Ellen’s wallet. Billy gets up from the bed, steps close to Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I know, its none of my business, but I just wanted to see something. Sarah hands Billy the wallet. CU: DRIVERS LICENCE, displaying Ellen’s picture. Billy looks up at Sarah. As we have seen earlier, the resemblance between Sarah and Ellen is prominent.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Unbelievable. Sarah glances at Billy, uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I got an idea. It just might work...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HIGHWAY ENTRANCE, DAY
dialogues.text: The convertible enters Interstate 10, going EAST. Upbeat MUSIC carries us through a montage of THE JOURNEY.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GRAND CANYON, DAY
dialogues.text: The young couple leans on the convertible staring at the vastness. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  13.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Beautiful but terrifying. She looks at him incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Why terrifying?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Anything that awesome makes me know for sure I’m gonna die.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Its late. Sarah is asleep. Billy can barely keep his eyes open. He reaches towards the dashboard, starts playing wi the dial of the radio. He tunes into an old Smashing Pumpkings song, hums along.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: .--- Shakedown 1979, cool kids never have the time - on a live wire right up off the street - you and I should meet ... Sarah opens her eyes, looks over toward Billy, smiles. Sh starts to recall the song as well. Tranquil, she sings al

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: ...dunebug skipping like a stone - with the headlights pointed at the dawn - we were sure we’d never see an en to it all - and I don’t even care ... faster than the speed of sound ...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HIGHWAY, EARLY MORNING
dialogues.text: Sarah and Billy are eating ears of corn from a road side stand as they get into the car and zoom back on the road. A dark figure in a baseball hat and sunglasses is parked the side of the road nearby. He watches and then pulls ou resuming his pursuit of the old convertible.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HIGHWAY, DAY
dialogues.text: The familiar yellow convertible is cruising along a highw A large sign indicates that Billy’s and Sarah’s journey h taken them south, as they cross the state-line into Alaba

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROAD, DAY
dialogues.text: The car comes to a stop at a small intersection. Sarah, engrossed in a local map, looks up. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  14. An oppressive sun beats down on the green landscape. Ther a large Billboard which reads: TREMO - WE’RE FRIENDLY FOL A dirt road extends toward the right. Sarah points.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: This way. Billy turns the wheel and onto a dirt road they go.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NILES ESTATE, DAY
dialogues.text: The car approaches a huge five-bedroom plantation-style mansion built in the civil-war years. The grounds are surrounded by large weeping willows and dense woods. Bill and Sarah climb out of the convertible and stare at in aw the estate of ZACHARY NILES IV. Once impressive the mansi is old and worn, the paint completely gone. They walk tow the large front door.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FRONT PORCH, DAY
dialogues.text: Billy moves to the left of the porch and starts searching top edge of the molding, framing two large windows. No lu

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I thought I’d try. Suddenly, a key drops onto the wooden porch. Puzzled, Sar and Billy look at each other. CU: Billy inserts the key into the lock. The heavy door slowly opens. A moment passes.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (under her breath) I don’t know... creepy shit. Billy hums “do-do, do=do,” the rhythmic twilight zone the Sarah nervously laughs at his teasing. Like Hansel and Gr the fairy tale, Billy and Sarah enter as bright sunlight floods the hallway. EXT. TREMO, ALABAMA - POPULATION 2003, DAY. A quiet and lazy day. The DARK FIGURE tailing Billy and S leans against a store window. A LIGHT BLUE EL CAMINO stop across the street. A LOCAL MAN and his TEENAGE SON get ou and disappear into a hardware store. The dark figure quic crosses the street, peaks inside the El Camino. The keys swing free in the ignition. The man jumps into the car and speeds away. Seconds later the truck’s owner comes running out of the hardware store dashes into the street as the El Camino drives past. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The interior of the mansion matches its outside. Everythi is on a large scale, dwarfing inhabitants as well as visitors. Inside the larger than life living room we see Billy, entrenched in a leather couch surrounded by numero hunting-trophies, stuffed exotic animals heads, which are displayed on the tall walls. Even though it’s morning and windows are wide open, the constant humidity is unfamilia unbearable to Billy. He appears anxious.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Sarah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah is busy preparing a pitcher of lemonade. We notice few grocery bags sitting on the counter, indicating that several days have past since the young couple’s arrival.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The EL CAMINO speeds down the road. The dark figure drivi is EDWARD ROMERO, a tough looking man in his early fortie with plenty of tattoos on his arms. A PISTOL with a two i custom silencer attached, slides about the passenger seat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah, wearing a sexy summer dress, strolls into the livi room, carrying two glasses of lemonade.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Thanks. Man, this heat. Billy sits up, sips the lemonade appreciatively. BILLY (CONT’D) Lets go over it one more time.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Again?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: The lawyer will be here at noon tomorrow. We gotta be on the same page or they’re not going to buy it. You got to know this stuff cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The El CAMINO comes over a rise and speeds toward the house. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  16.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: My name is Ellen Niles. I was born on February seventh, 1986, that makes me 21 years old. I visited my late, uncle Zachary, once, almost fifteen years ago. I don't really remember much because I was really young.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Why did Niles leave all his cash to Ellen - to you?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: He never had any children of his own. Besides my parents, who passed away recently, I'm his only living relative. Billy fires off the next question:

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: How did Niles get so rich?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: My grandfather was a hot-shot lawyer and developer in Pasadena.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Very good. Sarah's attention is caught by a large antique rifle abov the fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Look at this thing. She lifts the rifle from the wall. The weapon is a severa pounds too heavy for her, the long double barrel swings u and down. Billy nervously watches. Sarah smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward steers with one hand checking the pistol with the other.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Sure is heavy. Feels like lead. I wonder what he used it for?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: It’s a hunting rifle. Be careful... Intrigued, Sarah continues to examine the weapon. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  17. BILLY (CONT’D) Would you put that gun down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward pulls behind some bushes a little ways from the ho Shoving the pistol into his pants he gets out of the car cautiously approaches the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The long barrels of the gun keep swinging, pointing in Billy’s direction. Billy gets up and moves toward Sarah, attempting to push the rifle out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Put it away now. Please. Sarah, rifle in hand, walks up to Billy and kisses him softly.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: This old thing couldn't hurt a fly if it wanted to. She smiles seductively, steps backwards. Billy grabs for rifle, but latches onto the tip of the barrel instead. Sa laughs, then, suddenly, she trips and falls backwards. He falls on top of her. A playful mock fight breaks out betw the two. Sarah pushes Billy with one hand, rifle in the other. He leans in, kisses her. Sarah, still holding the rifle in one hand, moves forward and puts an arm around Billy. She carelessly throws the rifle away from her, ont the floor. As it hits the wooden planks: BOOM! The hunting rifle goes off, blasting out a front window. There's a definite THUMP, as somebody hits the po outside. Puzzled Billy and Sarah look at each other. Bill Sarah jump up from the floor.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Holy shit! Billy puts his index finger over his mouth, indicating to Sarah to be quiet. He stealthily heads out toward the por

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy opens the front door and looks out. Nobody. He sees small pool of blood in the dirt. Billy looks down: The pistol. Sarah moves up behind him, scared.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Maybe it was an... animal or something.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I don't think so. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  18. Billy holds up the gun and gives her an irritated look.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Look! Sarah points to the end of the driveway. The tail-end of El-Camino is sticking out from behind the bushes.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Stay here. Billy cautiously walks toward the car.

dialogues.speaker: INT. EL CAMINO, DAY
dialogues.text: Billy looks inside the truck. He opens the glove compartm and pulls out a registration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy walks back towards Sarah reading from the piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Car is registered to a Sal Marinaro. Right here in town.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I’m freaking out, Billy. Let’s go inside. Sarah turns to go inside the house. Billy remains standin

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You go ahead, I’m gonna look around. Take the gun, just in case. The safety is off, be careful. All you do is point and pull the trigger. Reluctantly Sarah takes it. Her hands are shaking. BILLY (CONT’D) Easy, easy. Listen, it was probably an accident.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about me playing with that old rifle. That was really stupid.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about it. Both are on edge. As Billy turns to leave, Sarah anxiousl smiles. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  19.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HIGHWAY, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Edward is staggering along the shoulder of a highway. Pal and exhausted, he is covering his blood-drenched abdomen his bare hands. A truck approaches, its bright headlights depict Edward in a grotesque and horrifying way. As the t speeds closer, Edward moves off the shoulder and hides be the highway. We FOLLOW the passing truck as a bright blue neon-sign, indicating a small MOTEL, emerges.

dialogues.speaker: INT. NILES MANSION, NIGHT
dialogues.text: A fan whirls overhead. The front door opens, Billy enters Sarah is sitting on the couch, the gun placed in front of her. She gets up, embraces him.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Thank God, you're back. I was worried.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I looked everywhere. There’s nothing but woods for miles. Whoever it was... disappeared. Billy picks up the pistol, crosses the room and places it into a drawer of a nearby bureau. He slides down next to Sarah, puts his head into her lap and sighing with exhaustion. BILLY (CONT’D) (Pause) You didn’t tell anyone about us coming here, did you?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Are you nuts? I can’t believe this.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I was only asking. (Pause) Wanna know what I think? I think some curious hillbilly stuck his nose into the wrong place at the wrong time, got some buckshot his ass and hightailed out of here. I honestly don’t think there is more to it.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What about the car? Somebody will be looking for it.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’1l make sure nobody’1l find it. Billy gently pulls Sarah closer.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MOTEL PARKING-LOT, NIGHT
dialogues.text: An elderly couple leaves one of the rooms. Edward watches them as the seniors go about their evening. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  20.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MOTEL ROOM, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dim light shines through the closed blinds. We hear NOISE Somebody is messing with the door-lock. Moments later Edw enters the room, shuts the door behind him, flips on the light, then quickly crosses towards the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BATHROOM, NIGHT
dialogues.text: CU: A PAIR OF TWEEZERS pulling out pieces of lead from a bloody wound. Edward sitting on a toilet, performing surgery on himself Biting on a bloody towel, he suppresses his painful agony

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tremo looks like a ghost town. A police car is parked out a convenience store.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SAL'S CONVENIENCE STORE, NIGHT
dialogues.text: SHERIFF ROBERT BROGDEN, JR. takes a report from SAL MARIN a heavy set man in his early sixties, owner of the stolen Camino. In the background is the Sheriff’s young deputy, EARL, twenty- something and skinny as a rail. Earl is a l shrewder than he looks. Sheriff Robert, early fifties, is often fumbling, a bit hot-tempered, yet, there is an innocent, almost naive core to him.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I saw him, Bob. Musta been a city hoodlum, ‘cause he got in there and got that son of a bitch hot wired in less than two seconds.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: (taking notes) ‘67 El Camino, light blue. License plate 228ZYX?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: That’s correct.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: And you could identify him if you saw him again?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Sure as the sun beatin' down on this place tomorrow will heat it to a hundred and ten. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  21.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: I’m gonna call in a sketch artist. I know every badge for five counties so there ain’t no way this guy gets away without me hearing about it. We’1ll get your truck back, don’t you worry Sal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah and Billy are in the midst of making love. Sarah’s is somewhere else. Breathless, she pushes Billy to the si

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I’m sorry ... its just... what about the gun? It has one of those things on top of it.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: A silencer.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Only a killer would use something like that. Some kind of assassin. Billy laughs, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Assassin? That silencer is a poorly made homegrown device. Please. Trust me, Sarah. Chances are we’re talking about some local cracker Joe. Nobody knows we're here and before you know it we'll be long gone and not a one ‘11 know what hit ‘em... Sarah remains silent. BILLY (CONT’D) Lets check this place out.

dialogues.speaker: INT. NILES MANSION/CELLAR, DAY
dialogues.text: Billy holds a flashlight as he pries the cellar door open After several attempts it opens. Cautiously Billy descend The space is cluttered with junk. He reaches out and dust off a cast iron sculpture of a stork. One knee is broken it still stands, almost three feet high. He turns to leav but a large framed painting catches his attention. It's a African hunting scene. Several dozen books fall to the gr as Billy removes a couple of old suitcases blocking the v INT. NILES MANSION - NILES’ BEDROOM, NIGHT The door opens. Light pours in from the hallway as Sarah enters. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  22. Next to a large book case is Niles' king-sized bed, a bur and desk. She flips on the light taking it all in. On the bureau is a beat up old record player, a stack of old rec next to it. Moments later classical music fills the room. Sarah sits down at the desk, starts rummaging through Nil elaborate wooden letter box. Dust flies everywhere. She coughs and fans the air with her hand, as she opens one o its drawers and pulls out several letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy sets the large painting on top of the fireplace man covering the shotgun. He stares at the painting for a mom then exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah sits at the desk, reading.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sarah?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I'm in here. Billy enters the bedroom and leans over Sarah’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: They're letters... love letters from a woman. Very romantic.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Great...I found a painting, might be worth something. Sarah keeps reading.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: They had a child.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: A child?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: But she was married and... and she knows it's his but she can't tell anyone.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Great. Last thing we need is somebody thinking they can get in on the money.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: This jerk didn't want to acknowledge his own kid. Listen to this... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  23.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "I know in my heart that this child is ours, no matter what you say, consummated in a moment that's special to me I beg you to acknowledge your son who, in your heart, you must know, is yours". I guess, she really loved him.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Maybe it wasn't his.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: It was his. "And the most painful of all is the rejection of your love for me and for our baby..." Sarah looks curiously at Billy. The record comes to an en and the needle crackles as it quits playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy finishes shaving, as Sarah enters the bathroom and hands Billy several sheets filled with the words "ELLEN NILES. Billy's studies the signatures.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I don’t think I could have done much better. Sarah smiles. Suddenly, the doorbell RINGS. Billy and Sar look at each other. Sarah checks her watch.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Twelve noon on the nose. Talk about punctual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERON BROGDEN is waiting on the porch. He's tall, very confident, strikingly good looking and well dressed. He checks his watch. The front door opens and Billy appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: How do you do? You must be...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: ...-Billy. Ellen's friend. Cameron extends his hand to Billy.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Cameron Brogden. It's good to meet you. Cameron smiles sincerely. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah, wearing her jacket, Billy and Cameron sit at a hug mahogany dining table. Papers and documents are spread ou all over the table. Cameron hands Sarah a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: You need to sign right there... But first I’‘1l need to see some picture ID: Birth- certificate, Passport, something like that. It’s just a formality. Sarah produces Ellen’s drivers licence, hands it to Camer then, calm and collected, takes the paper and whips off a "Ellen Niles". Cameron looks at the licence, appears satisfied. A slight smile crosses Billy's face.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ellen, I just wanted to express my deepest condolences. Your uncle had mentioned your parents’ terrible tragedy just days before the lord took him as well. May their souls rest in peace.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Thank you. Cameron picks up a picture of a young Ellen and her "Uncl Niles." The young Ellen has dark hair like Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: If you don’t mind me asking, when was the last time you saw your uncle?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Fifteen years ago, but you know... I was so young. I don’t remember much. Cameron nods. Although Sarah's response was correct, it c across a touch too prompt.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: When did you last talk to him? Sarah quickly glances at Billy, he doesn't know either. S pretends to be in thought, trying to remember.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Last time I talked to him?... I’m not really sure.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: If my memory serves me correctly, he mentioned a telephone conversation with you, about a month ago? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  25.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (thoughtful) Yeah, that’s sounds right...about a month ago. Around the time my parents died. Satisfied, Cameron nods, sets the picture back down. Sara wipes off the perspiration from her forehead. Billy notic

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Let me get you a glass of water. Billy gets up and disappears into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I apologize. I hope I’m not upsetting you any further.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I’m ok. Thanks. Billy returns with a glass of water. Sarah sips away.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Come on, let me show you around the property. Sarah can’t help herself:

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I have a... a question.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Of course?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: How much...what kind of inheritance, money are we talking about? I’m totally clueless. Billy stares at Sarah. The question hangs in the air.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I'm not exactly sure. I’1l forward you a complete list of assets, once I’m done with the assessment, but let’s just say, for now, your uncle was a prominent man. We're talking, maybe middle seven figure range.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SOUTHERN LANDSCAPE, DAY
dialogues.text: The sun beats down, as Cameron's 4X4 drives along a river

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAMERON'S 4X4, DAY
dialogues.text: Cameron drives, Sarah is in the passenger seat. Billy lea forward from the back. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  26.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: The river marks the edge of the land. Cameron stops the car.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SOUTHERN LANDSCAPE, DAY
dialogues.text: Cameron, Sarah, and Billy exit the truck and start walkin a steep hill. The winds are fierce. Sarah tries to keep h hat and dress from being blown off.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: At the top you’ll have a good look at the place.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE TOP OF THE HILL
dialogues.text: Billy, Sarah and Cameron overlook the river. Woods and sw in all directions. Some agricultural fields in between.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: (pointing) Right along there, that's the border. Not that anyone would ever dispute it. Back toward the Mansion at the edge of a field, a tractor lies on its side. Sarah spots it.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What’s the turned over tractor doing there?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: -.. that I’m afraid is where your uncle died. He passed out from the heat, flipped the tractor and struck his head. Sarah looks away.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I didn’t mean to be disrespectful. The sun is hurting Sarah’s eyes. She glances at Cameron, keeps her pose of gentility.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Let’s just go.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NILES MANSION, DAY
dialogues.text: Standing by his SUV, Cameron shakes hands with them.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: How long will it take, to settle everything? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  27.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Once the court approves your documents we should be able to transfer the cash accounts in two to three days. I can take care of selling this place. Of course you may want to consider hanging on to it... It sure is beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: It is, but it’s not for us. Thanks. Cameron steps inside his 4x4.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I'll check in with you tomorrow. I’11 do my best to make things as easy as possible. Have a good evening, folks.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Thanks very much. Sarah and Billy watch as Cameron’s 4X4 disappears.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: That guy makes me nervous.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You did great. Except, you shouldn’t have pushed so hard about the old man’s money.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What’s the difference? The only person that knew what Ellen really looked like died on that tractor. And you said I did good.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I said you did great.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAMERON'S OFFICE, DAY
dialogues.text: A large, well-appointed office. Leather furniture on plus carpet, paintings on the walls. In the center of the room see a big polished wooden desk with Cameron seated behind Sheriff Robert bursts in.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: You go over to Niles'? Cameron holds up an envelope marked "Niles".

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I got their file right here.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: What were they like? Cameron hesitates for a minute. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  28.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Seemed like a couple of nice young folks.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Sure. You can afford to be nice when you’re getting all that money. Cameron puts the file into his desk drawer, slams it shut

dialogues.speaker: INT. JOE'S DINER, EVENING
dialogues.text: The diner resembles an old fashioned Denny’s. Cameron and Sheriff Robert sit eating in a secluded booth.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Did you hear Sal’s truck was stolen?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: No kidding. Well, its the only El Camino in town. Shouldn't be too hard to track.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: That's just the thing, it up and disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I‘1l keep my eyes open. ALICE, the waitress, mid-thirties, a charming, typical southern “belle” approaches Sheriff Robert and Cameron. Currently single, she likes to show off her long legs.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Is everything all right with you boys? Cameron flashes his dazzling smile.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: It's just great, thanks. Alice takes the plates, smiles back at Cameron.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You call me if you need anything. Sheriff Robert watches as Alice saunters away.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: She's got the hots for you.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: The foreigners mention what they were going to do with the inheritance? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  29.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Didn't say.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Don't it strike you the least bit strange? Your Niles’ attorney all these years and he didn't leave you a dime, and instead he leaves all that scratch to some girl he barely knew.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Niles paid me my hourly price. It was fair and hardly cheap. And as for Ellen, she has a right to his equity by birth. It’s called inheritance Bob.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: (getting up) Anyway, gotta finish up another report. Burglary yesterday over at the Lazy Inn.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Sounds like you got a crime wave on your hands.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Yep. Plenty of action lately. And all started up since Niles kicked.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: But that was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: I’m starting to wonder. No one was asking for a coroner’s report. Maybe I should look into it. Sheriff Robert starts to get up from the table.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Do what you need to do, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: I just want everything...straight. For the record, y’know. He exits, giving a quick casual wave.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NILES MANSION, NIGHT
dialogues.text: A car approaches the front porch. Billy, dozing away wake and stands. The engine stops and an elderly woman emerges

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY WOMAN
dialogues.text: Good evening folks. My name's Belle. I used to be Mr. Niles' house keeper. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  30.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I'm Billy... Ellen's boyfriend. Did you need something from the house? Belle approaches the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the bedroom window Sarah looks down onto the porch watching Belle and Billy. Billy looks up, spots Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I baby sat for Mr. Niles years and years ago when Ellen was visiting. I bet she'll remember me. Billy and Belle sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah climbs down the stairs and moves toward the kitchen She stops as she sees a picture of Niles and Ellen on a bureau. Sarah glances at the picture and pulls her hair b the way Ellen used to wear it.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: What did you say your name was, again?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Billy. Belle reaches inside her handbag, pulls out a pen and a s scrap of paper and begins to write.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: Oh, Billy. I've been coming here, every other week for more than forty years, keeping this place tidy. He'd never would’ve had a home cooked meal if it weren't for me. He was never married, you know. Belle finishes writing, holding the paper out to Billy.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wouldn't mind keeping this place clean for you. If you might need me.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: That's real kind but we’re only gonna be here a short time. At that awkward moment, Sarah appears with a tray holding three glasses of ice tea. Excited, Belle stands up to get better look at her. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  31.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: Oh, Ellen. Look at you. Pretty as ever. You remember me? Sarah smiles, sits down.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I was...too young to remember, won’t you have some tea?

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: You've grown, but you haven’t changed a bit. You look just exactly like Mr. Niles. Belle continues to stare at Sarah. Sarah, uncomfortably l on. Billy smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I never thought it'd be the last time I saw him. It was so sudden. I can almost feel him watching us. Belle pulls out a handkerchief and wipes tear from her ey

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I know how you feel. Sarah reaches out and hugs Belle, looking at Billy with a helpless expression. Belle gets her composure back.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: How strange.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: You used to have a little beauty mark right there on your left cheek. Sarah looks at Billy.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Musta outgrown it.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: Yes, well, I better get going. You young people must have things to do. It was wonderful to see you, Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You too, Belle. Sarah and Belle get up, hug awkwardly one more time. Eventually, Belle lets go of Sarah then turns. Billy help her down the porch. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  32.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: Billy, right? You’re good people I can tell. You take good care of that little girl now... Belle gets in her car. Billy and Sarah watch as its tail- lights disappear into the night.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Beauty mark.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A police car approaches the old mansion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Robert drives. Earl sits in the passenger seat. Sheriff Robert hands him a camera with a long telephoto l attached to it.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Now, I want you to get some good pictures of the two of them.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Just do it, okay? Earl shrugs and pops two mouth full’s of chewing tobacco his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah, sitting on the porch, looks up and sees the police cruiser nearing. Moments later, Billy steps out of the fr door, leans against the entrance columns.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Visitors around the clock.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What the fuck do they want?

dialogues.speaker: INT. POLICE CAR, DAY
dialogues.text: The car comes to a halt in front of the large house. Sher Robert steps out of the car and moves towards Billy. Earl starts clicking away, taking pictures. Sarah notices and turns back into the house. CU: TELEPHOTO-LENS POV: CLICK. CLICK. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  33.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Sheriff Robert Brogden. Nice to make your acquaintance. He climbs the stairs toward Billy and shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: We're looking for a stolen car. An old El Camino. Light blue, metallic. Don’t suppose y’all would know something about it.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Sorry, we just arrived from out of town.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Sometimes kids’1l take a car out for a joy ride and dump it in the fields.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. POLICE CAR, DAY
dialogues.text: Earl steps out of the patrol-car, leans against the hood. attempts to spit a wad of tobacco juice onto the ground, the brown saliva won't separate from his mouth. Distracte Billy watches. Earl spits again, succeeds finally.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Wish I could help, but I haven't seen it. Sheriff Robert glances at the barn.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: You don't mind if we look around the property, do you?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: ‘appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: No problem. Quickly, Billy walks back into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earl joins the Sheriff as they slowly move towards the ba Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  34.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Did you get them pictures?

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. What are you up to Boss?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Routine is all, Earl. Always check where you least expect to find anything. That’s what my old man taught me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy enters, hastily moves to the bureau and retrieves t gun. He turns. Sarah is standing in front of Billy lockin eyes with him. Billy is on the edge.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Billy checks the cylinder, closes it.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Nobody is gonna get hurt. But we can’t afford to let that hillbilly arrest us.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You’re crazy! He tucks the gun into his pants, sidesteps Sarah, exits. Sarah rushes towards the window, watches the action unfol

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Robert and Earl stop at the yellow convertible. T Sheriff nods to Earl. Earl pulls out a paper-pad and penc writes down the license plate, then follows the Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE DRIVEWAY
dialogues.text: Walking swiftly toward the barn, Billy is closing in on t two police officers.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BARN
dialogues.text: Sheriff Robert and Earl arrive at the barn door.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Well, what are you waiting for? Open it up. Earl grabs the iron door handle and slowly slides the hea door open, inch by inch.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Honey? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  35. Sarah has stepped onto the porch wearing her jeans jacket Billy turns, stops. He stands halfway between the house a the barn, fingering the gun. The tension is about to clim when a car comes traveling down the dirt road. As Earl struggles to open the door, Billy squints at the approach car. Billy pulls his shirt tail over the pistol.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BARN
dialogues.text: Sheriff Robert spots the advancing car and starts walking back toward the house. Earl stops pulling on the door and follows Sheriff Robert. Through the partially opened barn the covered El Camino is visible. The 4x4 comes to a halt Cameron gets out of his car.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Bob, what are you doing bothering these nice people?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: I was looking for Sal’s truck.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Come on, Robert. You think you’1l find it around here? Not to mention you need a warrant to search people’s property.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Just making sure. (to Billy) Sorry to bother you. Let’s go, Earl. See ya later, Cameron. Sheriff Robert moves toward his cruiser. Earl follows.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NILES MANSION, DAY
dialogues.text: Cameron and Billy walk towards the front porch where Sara has been watching.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about our overzealous Sheriff. Been like that since we were kids.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Schoolyard pals?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Well in fact, he’s my brother.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Brother! Of course. Same last name! Brogden!

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Our father was the local sheriff for many years. I think Bob’s just trying to keep up. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  36.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s been a rash of crime around here lately. Tremo is a small town, drunk teenagers ‘bout the worst thing we get. Cameron and Billy arrive at the porch. Sarah steps into t frame, greets Cameron.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: How are you doing Mr. Brogden?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Doing just fine. Thanks for asking. Now, the reason for me stopping by... there’s been a hitch in your case. Billy’s face drops. Sarah looks worried. CAMERON (CONT’D) Why don't we all go inside and sit down? AT THE BARN: Someone is watching Sarah, Billy and Cameron

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three enter, sit down. The gun pokes into Billy’s bac

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: It's not that bad, really. It's just ...well, some guy in Las Vegas has filed an injunction.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: An injunction? Who?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I don't know, he's... he's claiming he’s Niles son.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Las Vegas? Very strange. Billy and Sarah are uneasy. Cameron notices.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Yes, it is strange. My gut feeling is, most likely, he’s somebody just looking for a quick pay off.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I don’t get it, doesn’t the will leave everything to me?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Yes, it does. However, if Niles didn't know he had a son, and then found out about it, and this individual could somehow prove that Niles had some intent to change his will ... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  37. There is an awkward silence. CAMERON (CONT’D) Option two... I suppose if you could prove that while Niles knew about this son and still left him nothing... Billy and Sarah look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Excuse me for a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah steps into Niles bedroom and starts searching the d A few moments later she finds what she is looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cameron reads Belle’s letter addressed to the old Niles, same letter Sarah discovered several nights ago.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Yes... this is very telling. I'm glad you showed this to me. It'll definitely make your case a lot stronger,...but you need something more.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: More?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Well, it's not his letter. What you need is something he's written, that specifically says he wants all of his estate going to Ellen, despite any other claims.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What are the odds of finding that? Cameron stands up, puts the letter into his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: No reason to get concerned. You see, the burden of proof is primarily on him, the rival party.... will take a little more time, but ‘round here there ain’t nothing but time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy sits inside the El Camino and turns the ignition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah steps outside and shouts at Billy who is driving by Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  38.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I'm getting rid of this damn car. Sarah watches as Billy drives the El Camino into the wood

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WOODS, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Billy steers the El Camino through the woods, toward a sw area. He stops at the edge of a muddy lake, steps out of truck, then reaches back inside the car. He is about to s the transmission into DRIVE when he notices a laminated c stuck near the drivers seat. He picks it up, pulls out a cigarette lighter, holds the flame close. It reads LA CAS CHECKING. “Edward Romero”. Billy stashes the card into hi pocket and leans back into the car. Moments later, the El Camino rolls into the lake, slowly disappearing. Billy wa until the taillights expire and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CONVENIENCE STORE, DAY
dialogues.text: Sarah exits the convenience store with a bag of groceries She gets into the yellow convertible, puts the bag onto t back seat. Suddenly her head is yanked backwards. It’s Edward, firmly pulling her hair. Sarah is about to scream

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: (calm, collected) Start the car or I’1l break your neck. Without hesitation Sarah slides the key into the ignition while peeking into the rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The convertible pulls out and disappears out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah is at the wheel, petrified. Edward, in pain, moves the front passenger seat. Wearing a odd Hawaiian shirt, h looks surprisingly good. One wouldn’t know he was shot on days earlier. He stares at Sarah with a menacing smile.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: You look real good, baby. Far cry from what I remember. Truly amazing this rehabilitation stuff. I’m proud of you. So, what do you want me to call you? Sarah? Or should I say, “Ellen”? Edward smiles, looks out the window. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  39.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Eddie...what...what are you doing here??

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: You think I’m stupid?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You gotta believe me, I don’t know what you’re talking about. We’re just passing through, paying our respects, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure. Without warning Edward strikes Sarah across the face. Temporarily, Sarah looses control of the car, which zigza on and off the shoulder. EDWARD (CONT’D) Keep your eyes on the road, sweetie! Sarah regains command of the convertible. She touches her face, notices blood dripping from her nose.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. Why you’re doing this?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: You know, I fucked Ellen right up the ass, she started singing about her wealthy folks, the charming uncle down in sweet home Alabama. And when you and the new boyfriend started heading south, I figured you weren't here for a memorial service. “Paying respects” my ass is what I say. Edward laughs. Sarah looks like she is ready to throw up. EDWARD (CONT’D) Let me ask you. Them drug meetings you go to, don’t they teach you about making amends to people you did wrong?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What? He jabs lightly but insultingly at the side of her face.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: I follow your little ass nineteen hundred fucking miles to this one horse hicktown, next thing I know I got a bullet in my gut. Edward lifts his shirt and reveals his bandaged abdomen. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  40.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Oh my God. It was an accident. I fell... I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: ‘appreciate the apology, baby. He lights up a cigarette. Sarah remains silent. EDWARD (CONT’D) Pull over.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OASIS INN MOTEL PARKING-LOT, DAY
dialogues.text: Sarah comes to a stop in the parking lot of a small motel sign above the front office reads: “Oasis Inn. Vacancy”.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: What’s the little fucker’s name? The boyfriend you’re dragging along?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: He’s just a guy. He’s nobody. As she speaks Edward has produced some white powder which is deftly packing into a pipe. He lights it, takes a drag

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Now you. He forces her to smoke the pipe, relighting it for her. N he leans into Sarah and touches her cheek. EDWARD (CONT’D) One more time. What’s his name?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Billy...

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Billy. Ok. Now, you keep it nice and quiet about me bumping into you... He slowly starts squeezing Sarah face tight, while pushin his thumb into her bloody nose. She screams in agony. EDWARD (CONT’D) ...-otherwise little Billy’s the first one to go. I’m here to collect. On Ellen’s behalf, so to speak. You follow me?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: (shaking, desperate) The lawyer says it’ll be a few more days before he’s going to transfer the assets. Edward lets go of Sarah’s face. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  41.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: And by the way. I want my piece back. Come by tomorrow. Any time between noon and three, Room 116... Edward simply looks at her. Sarah doesn’t know what to sa do. He mock-tenderly touches her chin.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I’ll be there. Edward pulls out a small plastic bag and drops it between Sarah's legs.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Just that you know, I’m with you, Sarah. I know, you got your head all mixed up from all that rehab mambo-jumbo. I say, treat yourself. Life’s short. Enjoy the moment. Know what I mean? Edward turns to the backseat, grabs the bag of groceries, then slowly drags himself out of the car. He slams the passenger door shut, smirks as he leans into the car.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Man... impossible to tell you two birds apart. (Pause). See you tomorrow. Terrified, Sarah floors the gas-pedal and looks into the view mirror, as Edward moves out of focus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Robert pulls up next to a COUNTY POLICE CAR. Carr an envelope, he proceeds into the station.

dialogues.speaker: INT. POLICE STATION, DAY
dialogues.text: Sheriff Robert enters his sparse office. Sal is sitting n to a desk, talking with a young female sketch artist, MEL

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Sal.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Afternoon. Hot enough for you?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: I suppose, I suppose. Sheriff Robert looks at the sketch. It's taking shape.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mel, I was starting to think you weren't coming. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  42.

dialogues.speaker: MEL
dialogues.text: Come on, Robert. A stolen truck in Tremo ain’t exactly the crime of the century. Sheriff Robert opens the envelope and takes out several s shots of Billy and Sarah. He shows the pictures to Sal.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Is this him? Sal takes the photographs and studies them...

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: That ain't him, Bob, but I seen the girl. She comes by the store every so often. Matter of fact she bought a bag full of groceries just a few hours ago.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Are you sure it ain't him?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: One hundred percent. Why? What’d they do?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Oh, nothin’. Just hopin’ for a grounder. Disappointed, Sheriff Robert puts the pictures back into envelope. Mel shows Sal her drawing.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah... his face was a little rounder, a little fuller. Mel continues to make the changes. Sheriff Robert looks h at the picture, as Edward's face starts to show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The convertible is parked in the driveway. Sarah, torment pulls down the sun-visor, checks her face in the vanity- mirror. She pulls out a handkerchief and removes the drie blood from below her nose. The small plastic bag packed w dope sits on the passenger seat. CU: Pipe, as Sarah lights up. Suddenly there is a knock on the car-window. Sarah scream Its Billy, looking straight at her, puzzled. Sarah is sti holding the pipe. Billy opens the car door and slides in. Tense silence follows.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I thought you were done with that. Where did you...? Sarah, trying to act ‘normal’ as best as she can. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  43.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I found a little with Ellen’s stuff. That and the pipe. You know, with all the shit that we’re dealing with, I feel like its ok to have a little... fun. You’re mad?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’m not mad. Hey, if it makes you happy.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I want us both to be happy.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Alright. Then I deserve to have a little fun as well, don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Billy reaches out and takes the pipe and the lighter from hands. Sarah is unsure, nervous.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Are you sure about this? Last thing I wanna do is get you hooked on dope.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Not to worry. Let’s party together. Just like one time, ok? Sarah hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Ok. Billy lights up the pipe, inhales. Sarah watches.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: That...is pretty good. A big blissful look comes over Billy’s face. He kisses he Sarah responds, kisses him back, as the two drop into oblivion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy eyes are wide open while Sarah appears to be sound asleep. Several moments pass. Then:

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: There is a way out of this. Sarah slowly opens her eyes. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: BILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remember when I said that everybody has a history? I used to forge documents for a living.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You what?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Back in Vegas I worked with this friend of my brother’s. Dean. Very cool guy, really taught me stuff. We forged passports, birth, death certificates, pink-slips, insurance claims, you name it. He had a fully equipped trailer in his backyard. Let me tell you, that trailer was something else. Super high tech. Anyway, there was this girl I knew from high-school. Long story short: Prom- night she crashes her mom’s car into a casino. Right on the strip. Put to icing on the cake she pulls out a fake ID. Get it? Well, that was the end of it. FBI and what not. I did a year in juvenile hall, then six months in jail. Sarah can’t believe her ears. BILLY (CONT’D) Point is, I was thinking about taking a closer look at Niles’ letters. The problem is, if I get caught... I’m going away for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: So, what, you're like a forger? A scam artist. What the ...?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Not anymore. That’s in the past. Sarah turns over.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: And what do you call us being here? Its a scam. Billy, you say that your mother is a minister and runs a wedding-chapel. And what about your brother and this business thing in LA? I’ve never seen you call him once. Do you really expect me to believe any of it?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute. I said my mom used to be a minister. She’s retired now... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  45.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Stop it. I’m not an idiot, you know. I don’t care about what you used to do, your history... Actually, the less you say, the better. I like you for who you are. For some very bizarre reason I even trust you. Just... don’t lie anymore. There is long pause. Then:

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I was only trying to find a quick and easy way out of this.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I think we should get out of here. That's quick and easy. Ellen’s dead. Stealing her money... Billy, nothing is right about any of this. It’s a delicate situation. After a moment:

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: We're this close and you’re doing really good. I say, let’s play along a bit longer, see what happens. If it gets too dicey, we split. What do you think? Sarah hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Let’s sleep on it. Billy smiles, kisses her. He notices a cut on Sarah’s lip

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What happened to your lip?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I bit on it. Had a bad dream. A little to prompt of an answer. Suddenly her head pops u

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: There’s something out there. Sarah jumps out of bed and pokes her head into the hallwa Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  46.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Sarah toward Niles' bedroom then turns back to Billy, her face ashen. She holds her finger to her mouth. Billy grab flashlight off the night stand and joins her.

dialogues.speaker: NILES BEDROOM
dialogues.text: A DARK FIGURE has lifted up a few floor boards.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Billy aims his flashlight at the figure. POP! Billy turns the flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: NILES BEDROOM
dialogues.text: The INTRUDER looks up. He's on his hands and knees, his e glow, as the light reflects off his pupils. He's short an stocky, with long dark hair...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey! .-.and the intruder is gone.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sarah, turn on the light! Sarah searches for the light switch.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I can’t find it! Suddenly there’s a noise as Billy and Sarah watch the fig jump out the open window. Quickly, the two move back towa their bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Stay inside and lock the door! Billy darts down the stairs. Sarah slams the bedroom door

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NILES MANSION, NIGHT
dialogues.text: The intruder leaps onto the porch roof then down to the ground. He doesn't miss a beat but he unintentionally dro VIDEO TAPE, as he escapes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy rushes down the stairs, goes to the bureau and remo the pistol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy storms out of the house. The intruder jumps on a di bike nearby, fires it up. Billy aims the gun but hesitate Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  47. The intruder races away and disappears into the woods. Bi notices the video tape lying in the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy and Sarah stand around the open floor boards. Sever hundred dollar bills litter the floor.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: That guy knew exactly where the old man kept his stash. Billy kneels down, points his flashlight underneath the f boards and discovers several gay porno magazines.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: .-..and his “personal” secrets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy pops the video tape into the VCR, presses play. CU: TV. Blurry home-video images. Two naked men on a larg plush bed are kissing. It’s the Intruder and Niles Zachar The camera zooms in on Zachery Niles’ face, as the Intrud “disappears below” to please old Zachery.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We're having fun now, aren't we Zachary? Another scene. This time Niles and another man, dressed i eighteenth century wig and white make-up, are tied to a contraption inside a phony candlelit dungeon. Classical m plays in the background as a hooded figure in black leath enters and whips the chained men.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who is your master, you sissies? Who is your master? Billy hits the remote, turns off the TV set. Billy and Sa look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Well, he was your uncle..

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Very funny...

dialogues.speaker: INT. JOE'S DINER, DAY
dialogues.text: Sheriff Robert sits at the counter talking to JOE, early sixties, wearing a stained cooks uniform. Joe also owns t place. The sketch of Edward sits on the counter, the pict of Billy and Sarah next to it. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  48.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Never seen the mean looking one. But think I’ve seen them around. Those are the kids staying out at Niles’ house, right? The jackpot winners. Sheriff Robert puts the pictures back into his envelope. Alice checks the ticket spindle, addresses Joe.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Joe, you're going to take care of them orders or do I have to go back there myself?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Just talking to the Sheriff, doll. Earl enters the Diner, carrying a folder.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Bob, is your brother seeing anyone?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
