dialogues.text: No, he's still Tremo's most eligible bachelor. I'll mention you asked though.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I wish you would. Earl arrives and takes the seat next to Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: I ain't seein' no one, Alice.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I "ain't" teaching pre-school.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: She’s saying you're wet behind the ears, son.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: You don’t know what you’re missing, Alice. Alice rolls her eyes and moves off to her other customers

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: These kids in some kind of trouble Bob?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: No, no. Routine police work is all, Joe. Something catches on fire in the kitchen. Joe takes off running. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  49.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: I’ve got something important to relay to you, Sheriff..

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Well, ... what is it?

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: I got what you’ve been waiting for.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Yes? Earl, what am I waiting for?? Spit it out!

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Sheriff, they faxed us the Coroner's report. Earl pushes the report over to the Sheriff, who hastily o the envelope. Earl can’t resist revealing the highlight.

dialogues.speaker: EARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It rules out heat stroke as the cause of death. It says he died from suffocation. Now ain’t that a pisser? Sheriff Robert studies the report.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: I‘1l be damned. I got myself a murder in Tremo.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MOTEL ROOM, DAY
dialogues.text: Edward lies in bed, smoking, watching TV. Wrestling. Ther a KNOCK. Edward quickly get up, peeks through security-ho It’s Sarah. Edward opens the door, pulls Sarah inside.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Glad you could make it. He steps up to her, reaches inside Sarah’s jacket and pul out his gun. Edward checks the pistol, stares at Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, first you forget to say “I’m sorry”. Now, not even a “thank you”? Sarah doesn’t understand. EDWARD (CONT’D) My little present to you, yesterday. That was prime cut.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Thanks. She looks around the room not knowing what to say. Then: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  50.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought you might wanna know... this whole thing turns out to have lots of kinks. It could take months.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Really? Well, you just have to tell that lawyer you need the money now. You’re Ellen Niles, its your money baby, right?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What if I can’t? Edward moves close, touches her hair. Sarah is petrified.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Don’t say you can’t. You can. You’1ll do as I say and all will be good.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I got the gun like you asked. Edward doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I better leave.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Already? It does get awful lonely ‘round here. Let’s play a little...huh? What do you say? Edward starts kissing her. He murmurs to her seductively, interrupting the kisses. EDWARD (CONT’D) Back in the day...when Ellen was around...you was always looking at me kinda friendly like...curious sorta...

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Stop it! Don’t. I don’t... Edward grabs her shoulders and throws her onto the bed. H looks are stone cold.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: There is lots of swamps around here. Nobody’d find you in a million years. You better start bein’ cooperative.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What...? Edward unbuckles his belt, unzips his pants and grabs Sar wrists, pushing his free hand into her pants. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  51.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Leave me alone!! Don’t... I can’t... Don’t do this please....

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Don’t fuck with me you good for nothing crack bitch! You already got one foot in the grave. You’d best concentrate on transferrin’ some of them assets into my fucking wallet, or I swear I’1l kill the both of you. Attempting to fight Edward off, Sarah scratches his face. It’s of no use as he pushes her down into the bed.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Get of f!!!! Edward continues his assault. Tears cover Sarah’s face. I the background the TV roars as wrestling match comes to a brutal climax.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC -
dialogues.text: A hot summer day. Overcast skies. We see Billy and Sarah swinging high above the smooth waters of an abandoned min lake via a make shift swing. Dressed in cut-off jeans, bo are laughing, teasing each other, while swaying back and forth below the vast branches of large overgrown trees, reaching beyond the edge of the lake. Eventually both rel their grip as their skinny bodies plunge into the blue wa We watch as the two are swimming below the surface of the lake ascending toward the blurry sunlight. Moments of joy young innocent love follow. Billy and Sarah are necking e other while embracing and kissing, holding on to one anot subsiding and rising between the water surface. Lounging inside a car’s inner tube, Sarah puffs a cigarette, blowi smoke into Billy’s face. She laughs innocently. Both gigg away and engage in a mock fight as Billy splashes water o Sarah, rocking the rubber tube. Ultimately the black makeshift lounge-chair tips over as the two disappear int the depths of the lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU: BILLY, asleep, dreaming away. Except the TV’s static house appears pitch dark. Billy’s eyes open. He hears the sound of food being prepared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU: Two pieces of chicken frying inside a pan. Trying to forget what she went through with Eddie, Sarah, tense, mechanically prepares a meal. Moments later Billy walks into the kitchen. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  52.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Wow. Real home cookin’. You’re a real chef.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I got lots of talents you don’t know about.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What’s that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I mean we only just met for God’s sake.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Well, I think we’re starting to know each other pretty good.(Pause) Where have you been?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Went into town while you were sleeping. Store was closed. I drove around, got lost. I hate this place. Not one god damn supermarket. Billy sits down at the kitchen table. After a moment:

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You’re ok? You look... stressed out.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: It’s the heat.

dialogues.speaker: INT. POLICE STATION, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Cameron is sitting at his brother’s desk, glancing at his files. He picks up the phone, dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah turns away from Billy, runs into the dining-room to pick up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Ellen, its Cameron Brogden on the line. Sorry to call so late at night, but, I have some, well, disturbing news. Sarah coughs into the phone. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  53.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Excuse me. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I’ve had a look at a coroner’s report concerning your uncle and it appears that he didn’t die of natural causes. It looks like he was suffocated. Its been ruled a homicide. I’m terribly sorry. Sarah pauses. Billy steps into the room, listening. Sudde a wave of nausea comes over Sarah. She puts her hand over mouth, as vomit spews from between her fingers. She drops phone and doubles over. CAMERON (V.O.) (CONT’D) Ellen...Ellen? Are you alright? Ellen gestures to Billy to stay back as she gets to her f

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I’m just not feeling well right now.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Miss, I realize this must come as a shock to you...

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: +.. who would want to kill that sweet old man?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I wish I knew the answer. Another thing: Please be advised that the sheriff might stop by tonight.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: The Sheriff?? What does he want?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He'll probably examine the tractor, ask a few routine questions.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Well, I didn’t kill him if that’s where you’re going with this. And neither did Billy.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ellen, I had no intention of even remotely suggesting such an indecent premise. I’m truly sorry. Listen, don’t you worry. I promise you I’1l do my very best and handle this unfortunate situation. Meanwhile, let’s keep the conversation to the parties involved, let’s not upset the Sheriff any further, if you know what I mean. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  54.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, thanks for calling...

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's the part of my profession I hate, breaking such awful news. Ellen, I’1l be prayin’ for you and I'll keep you posted. Sarah hangs up the receiver. Concerned, Billy approaches Sarah, handing her a towel.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Well, this whole deal just got a whole lot more fucked up than it was already...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What? Sarah smiles a bitter smile.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Sheriff ‘Bob’ ordered a coroner’s report and just got the results. Niles’ death is now officially a homicide. Excuse me... She rushes for the nearest bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Fuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy and Sarah sit on the porch, waiting. In the distanc police-car slowly drives into view.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Here they come. Sheriff Robert and Earl step out of the police car and wa up to the porch. Billy and Sarah sit there, doing their b imitation of a decent rural couple out of American Gothic

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Folks. Sorry to bother you at this hour.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: As of today this plot of land’s a crime scene in a homicide investigation. Me and Earl are gonna do some dusting for fingerprints on your Uncle’s tractor. We thought to be polite we should pay you kids a visit, first. Billy gets up. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  55. SHERIFF ROBERT (CONT’D) Where you goin’ son?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Can’t wait to see a team of crack law enforcement professionals at work...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FIELD, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Flashlights expose the tractor Cameron pointed out earlie Sarah and Billy. Two officers dust it for fingerprints. Sheriff Robert, Earl and Billy are in the background.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: How are we doing boys?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Looks like we've got a whole bunch of clean prints.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Cracked the case, Sheriff?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Still investigating. You don't mind if we take a few fingerprints, do you?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: No. Make yourself at home.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: This time we need yours and Miss Niles. If you two could fall by the station tomorrow morning it’d sure be appreciated.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Fingerprints? What for?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Tradition here in Tremo, kinda a keepsake to remember you by. Ain’t that right Earl? Earl smirks away. Billy stares at the Sheriff with contem SHERIFF ROBERT (CONT’D) Seriously. What do you think, smartass? I need your prints to see if they match what we just collected. So we can crack the case. Get it?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You got some fucking nerve to show up here in the middle of the night... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  56.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: ++. now, don’t get yourself all worked up, boy. Just doin’ my job. Be at the station ten AM sharp. Have a good night.

dialogues.speaker: COLLAGE OVER MUSIC
dialogues.text: A series of “MOMENTS”, showing the principal characters, entrenched in thought, contemplating. The idea is that of brief time-out. 1) EXT. TREMO - DESERTED, NIGHT. Establishing. 2) INT. OFFICE, NIGHT: Cameron, in his dimly lit office, up on his desk, smoking a cigar, staring out of the windo into the dark. 3) INT. BEDROOM - SOMEWHERE IN TREMO, NIGHT: Sheriff Robert’s, rolling around in his bed, unable to sleep. 4) INT. BEDROOM, SOMEWHERE IN TREMO, NIGHT: The Intruder, glancing at the ceiling of his room. A tense look in his eyes, as he takes a long drag of a cigarette. 5) INT. NILES MANSION - BATHROOM, NIGHT - CU: Sarah, sitt on the bathroom-floor, eyes barely open. Next to her we notice her drug gear. 6) INT. OASIS INN MOTEL, NIGHT: Edward, lying on his bed, eyes wide open, staring at the TV, which displays nothing static. Periodically he takes a sip from a can of beer. 7) INT. NILES MANSION, NIGHT: Billy, lying on one side of bed, eyes open, pondering.

dialogues.speaker: INT. POLICE STATION, DAY
dialogues.text: An overhead projector blasts images of fingerprints onto screen. Sheriff Robert, Cameron, Earl, and DOTTY, a middl aged forensic scientist, look at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: DOTTY
dialogues.text: These are the fingerprints you lifted off of the tractor... She points to several spots on the prints.

dialogues.speaker: DOTTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -.-and as you can see they belong to two different people...

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Any matches? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  57.

dialogues.speaker: DOTTY
dialogues.text: One belonged to Mr. Niles, but the other one... we don’t have a match.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) A murder, an unidentified suspect, a stolen car... Cameron glances at his brother.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Don’t look at me Bob, I’ve never been involved in something this complicated.

dialogues.speaker: INT. YELLOW CONVERTIBLE, DAY
dialogues.text: Billy is at the wheel. Sarah stares out of the window watching the trees go by.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Nothing but trees, swamps and boiling heat. I don’t know how anybody can live here.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I think I’1l do it.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Forge the letter. Might just be worth the risk.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to do anything stupid. I mean that. But, if you think it’d get us out of here faster... murder, weird hillbilly sex-tapes, not to mention that I shot somebody. Accident or not. This is a bad bad fucking nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: We'll get through this, I promise. Sarah slides close to Billy, presses tight against him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy and Sarah sit as Earl and a matron take their fingerprints. Sheriff Robert paces. Cameron watches.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Where were you two the Sunday before last? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  58.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Bob, you are crossing the line. (to Billy and Sarah) You don't have to answer that.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Was that the day he was killed? Ellen and I were in LA. Guess what? We can prove it, too.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: I certainly hope so. (beat) How much you think old man Niles was worth, Billy?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What is with you? You don’t have a shred of evidence against us. We don’t even have to be here, except for courtesy.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: He’s just being mean Billy, don’t let him bother you.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: The young lady happens to be correct Bob. Why don’t you just lay off. Earl, nods to the matron, hands Billy and Sarah paper-tow

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: We’re all done here. Sheriff Robert steps into Billy's face, blocking him.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: People do some real crazy shit to get their hands on a winning lottery ticket. Even a hick-town sheriff knows that. Somehow, right from the jump, I could tell that you boy, are nothing but a bad piece of news.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You could tell, huh? What is this?? Listen, I know my rights. May I go now?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: I bet you do know your rights. Bet you had plenty of scrapes with the law...

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Bob, I have to protest. This is... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  59.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: ...it’s my office Cam, my investigation. (pause) In case I haven’t been clear, sooner or later I’m gonna nail your maggot ass to the wall. I don’t care how long it takes. Down here we follow law and order. You missed the big sign outside of Tremo. Know what it reads? Not welcome! Have a nice day! Billy moves around Sheriff Robert, takes Sarah’s hand and exits. Cameron follows them outside.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: What do you think Boss? We gonna get them bastards?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: It'll be like shootin’ deer in a pen.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. POLICE STATION TREMO, DAY
dialogues.text: Billy and Sarah come storming out of the building. Camero one step behind the couple.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I'm really sorry about what happened in there. My brother’s a good man. He is just a bit too eager at times. Billy thinks for a moment, then:

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Should I’ve told him about the guy, that broke into the house a few nights ago... Maybe Niles was mixed up in something... you know...something...fucked up.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Were you able to get a look at this guy, this “intruder”? Could you ID him?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Short with long, dark hair... kinda stocky.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Did he take anything?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’m not sure. He tried. He exchanges a glance with Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: We didn’t bother you about it but with the Sheriff pulling all this nonsense... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  60. Billy’s tentative. Something's not right. But they’ve gon this far.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: The guy dropped something on his way out. A videotape. Sarah and Billy share another glance.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Uncle Niles is on it and uhm, it’s, well, it’s not altogether pleasant to look at.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: If it’s all right, I’d like to see it for myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah, Billy and Cameron enter the mansion’s entrance-hal

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: If you'll excuse me I’m going to lie down, see if my stomach can settle. Sarah disappears up the staircase.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Good day, Miss Niles.

dialogues.speaker: THE LAST IMAGES OF THE PORN TAPE
dialogues.text: Billy presses “Eject”. Seconds later a tape pops out. Cam looks on, however, Billy's back is blocking the view. Bil tape in his hand, gets up and turns to Cameron. CAMERON (CONT’D) Wow! Billy nods and hands Cameron the tape.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ll get rid of this dirt. Niles had a respectable reputation, and I don’t see how its being tainted now will serve our cause particularly...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Would Nile being gay, weaken the claims of an illegitimate son?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Not significantly I’m afraid. The phenomenon of men with homosexual tastes fathering children isn’t that rare. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  61. Cameron puts the cassette into his briefcase. The lowerin sun beams inside the living room, hitting Billy in the ey He moves to the window to lower the blinds.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I gotta question.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Go right ahead.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: In your professional opinion, how much longer is this whole ordeal gonna last?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Well, once foul play is suspected, Alabama probate court will put an immediate hold on the case. I’d say at least a month, closer to two. The blinds won’t lower. Billy pulls on it, but it’s stuck

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: A month or two? I don’t think we can stay that long. Billy twists the cord way over to the right, then rips it back to the left. Finally the blinds lower.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Are you folks strapped for cash? Since I do have power of attorney, it wouldn't be improper for me to advance you some money.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What did you have in mind?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: How about five thousand dollars? Billy responds without hesitation.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: We'll wait... for the settlement.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I understand. Do you know anything about art, Billy? Cameron moves towards the mantel and points to the painti Billy retrieved from the cellar. Billy shrugs no.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, Niles' taste in art was...pretty eclectic. I think he paid a hundred and thirty five thousand for that one. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  62.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I imagine you could get at least twice that much at any art auction. Billy moves closer to the painting. Two men aim muskets a large white elephant that is fleeing across a river in th African bush country, while African natives look on.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: A hundred thirty five thousand bucks? For this? Cameron nods. They both look at the painting.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Must be nice to have that kind of cash...

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t know...I should get going. He heads for the front door, resumes the avuncular mode. CAMERON (CONT’D) I hope Ellen feels better. And trust me, it’ll all work itself out. They’re at the door. Billy opens it to let him out.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Thanks for everything. Billy watches as Cameron drives away then shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CABIN, NIGHT
dialogues.text: A red scarf covers the only light bulb inside the small r The walls are decorated with male pin-ups. JAMIE ALBRIGHT twenty eight, sits on a bed. We recognize him as the intr Billy chased out of Niles' house several nights ago.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: I tried my best. It's not my fault he gave you the wrong tape. Cameron stands behind him. Both look at the television se IT'S AN INSTRUCTIONAL TAPE FOR A NEW LINE OF TRACTORS.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you sore at me? I did everything you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Yes you did.

dialogues.speaker: JAMIE
dialogues.text: Don’t be mad at me. Cameron glares at Jamie. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  63.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I'm not mad. I’m not mad at all. Cameron takes off his belt with its monogrammed buckle. CU: TELEVISION SET, as the tape continues to play. In the BACKGROUND we hear the SOUNDS of a struggle: Bits and pie of squelched words, brief shouts and screams. CU: JAMIE. A leather belt is tightened around his neck. A infuriated Cameron glances at the TV while his hands grap at the ends of his belt. Suddenly, the buckle flies off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah walks into the kitchen. Billy is sitting at a table with a phone book. Sarah sits in his lap, kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Trying to get to the other side of the story. I think Mr. Cameron Brogden is jerking us around.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What about the letter?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: We may not need it. Billy looks up. BILLY (CONT’D) You're ok?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I’m fine. Sarah gets up, moves to the refrigerator, pulls out a car of milk and fills a cup.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You look pale.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Really? Well,... thanks! Sarah takes a sip.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You don’t think I know what’s going on with you?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  64.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You slept for fourteen hours that’s what's wrong. Listen to me. You need help. Go back to LA... go back into rehab if that’s what it takes. I’1l stay, get the money and we’ll meet up when I’m back. Sarah looks at him in disbelief. She bursts out:

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You know what Billy? I just wish you’d get your act together and forge that goddamn letter. All you do is talk and talk and wait and wait. I’m sick of this fucking place.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You don’t think I know that you’ve been shooting up? Sarah, unsure of herself, stares at Billy. BILLY (CONT’D) One look into your eyes and I know exactly what you’ve been doing. You think about what I said. Unless you want to wind up like Ellen.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You’re wrong. Billy gets up and moves close to her.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’m gonna go out on a limb here. And keep in mind that this is only to prove how much I care for you. I believe you... He takes her hand and turns her arm over. Fresh bruises c her arm. Sarah looks away.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: +.-until its true. Sarah breaks down, sobs. Billy reaches out and pulls her his arms.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I’1l quit. Soon. When this is over. We’re in this together... Sarah slides away from Billy, walks out of the kitchen. B looks after her. He sits down and flips through the phone book, to... lawyers. He sees Cameron's ad and one other l ad for SLY WHEATON, the only other lawyer in Tremo. It's already been circled in thick black ink. Billy rips out t page, slams the phone book shut and dials. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  65.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Mr. Wheaton, Sly Wheaton? Hi. I’m calling regarding with the estate of Zachary Niles.

dialogues.speaker: INT. POLICE STATION, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sheriff Robert sits at his desk. Dotty enters with a file

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Any of the prints match?

dialogues.speaker: DOTTY
dialogues.text: No match. But remember that fella who used to work for Niles, Jamie Albright? Turns out he had some priors and his prints were as clear as day. Sheriff Robert gets up, grabs his jacket and storms out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out in the middle of nowhere. Two police cars are parked to the small cabin. A familiar looking dirt bike leans against the porch railing.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CABIN, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sheriff Robert sees Jamie's naked body lying on the bed. Dead. TWO OFFICERS examine the corpse. Earl pokes around.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Boy was strangled... don’t look like forced entry though. Earl laughs while glancing at the male pin-up posters.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Earl, why the fuck are you wearing sun glasses at night? Large aviation glasses cover Earl's eyes. He spits a wad dark tobacco juice into a cup.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Makes me look meaner. Sheriff Robert sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy drives along Main street. He spots a parking space pulls in. Billy gets out of the car, examines the page fr the telephone book. Blinded by the bright sun, Billy stum across the street. HONNNNK! A car barely misses him. Bill looks at the numbers. 52, next to that 56. He wanders int alley, looks up. 54. Sly Wheaton's office. Billy enters. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  66.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SLY WHEATON'S OFFICE, DAY
dialogues.text: Noticeably less plush than Cameron's office. SLY WHEATON, poorly groomed man in his mid fifties sits at the desk, talking on the phone. In addition to a tacky suit, he wea gallon of styling gel in his hair. As soon as he sees Bil

dialogues.speaker: SLY, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: I got to go. He puts the receiver down.

dialogues.speaker: SLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hi-ya. William, I take it?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: That’s me. You can call me Billy, if you want.

dialogues.speaker: SLY
dialogues.text: Sit...sit down. Billy obliges.

dialogues.speaker: SLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've come to settle up? Must say though, I thought I was going to have to file before I ever saw any money outta you.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Settle up?

dialogues.speaker: SLY
dialogues.text: Must be a lot of people tryin' to horn in on the inheritance?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Well, yeah, that's what I wanted to talk to you about.

dialogues.speaker: SLY
dialogues.text: What'cha drinking? Sly pulls out a bottle of gin and two glasses from below desk.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’m fine, thanks. Sly looks up.

dialogues.speaker: SLY
dialogues.text: Suit yourself. You don't mind if I do? Billy shakes his head. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  67.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I just need some advice, possibly representation. I can pay you, as soon as... Sly starts laughing.

dialogues.speaker: SLY
dialogues.text: I bet you can. Billy leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: -.. lets say... suppose the old man had an illegitimate child that was trying to get some of his money. What would be the quickest way to find some kind of solution?

dialogues.speaker: SLY
dialogues.text: Solution? Kill'em. Sly laughs out loud, then shifts gears to serious.

dialogues.speaker: SLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You need a document stating that Niles wanted his money going to his niece, and his niece only.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Well, I don't have that document. Sly smiles and nods, takes a sip from his glass.

dialogues.speaker: SLY
dialogues.text: You've got a problem then, don't you? I bet Niles knew all about this ‘cause he came to me two days before he passed away. He was going to have me change his will to explicitly exclude anyone... but Ellen. Sly lets this sink in. Billy's mind races.

dialogues.speaker: SLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want that drink now? Sly pours Billy a drink and slides the glass toward Billy then pours one for himself and quickly drains it.

dialogues.speaker: SLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kind of a coincidence, don't you think? He ends up dead right before he intends to change his will.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You could testify... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  68.

dialogues.speaker: SLY
dialogues.text: ...for a price.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: This has already gone on forever.

dialogues.speaker: SLY
dialogues.text: It'd be worth it. I already started the paperwork for the old man. Listen, why don't you leave me a check for the three thousand Niles owed me? You know, to show good faith. Mind you, I ain’t charging an arm and a leg like Cameron Brogden.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I don't have three grand. Sly leans back in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: SLY
dialogues.text: Well, then you better get it. We all gotta eat, you know.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: That’s a fact. Anyway, thanks for your time. I’1l call you.

dialogues.speaker: SLY
dialogues.text: Anytime.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE ELBOW-ROOM-BAR, DAY
dialogues.text: Several locals are sitting quietly inside the dark wateri hole. Soft countrymusic plays in the background. GEORGIA, bartender, a woman in her sixties, sporting a Coors baseb cap, is fixated on solving her crossword puzzle. The Sher enters, takes a seat at the bar-counter. Georgia looks up

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA
dialogues.text: Sheriff Robert? What a surprise. Haven't seen your charmin’ face in long time. How’s everythin’ ?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Its going. Its going.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA
dialogues.text: How about a cold one?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Sure sounds good, Georgia. Sheriff Robert opens an envelope, pulls out several sketc of Edward, along with pictures of Billy and Sarah. Georgi places a tall glass of tap beer in front of the Sheriff. glances at the photos. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  69.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA
dialogues.text: Crime suspects?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Yup. Any of them faces look familiar? Georgia glimpses at the sketch of Edward, looks at it aga

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA
dialogues.text: I know him. Dangerous kinda fella, I tell ya.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: You know this man? Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m sure. He was sitting right here. I even talked to him.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: What did he say ?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA
dialogues.text: I don't know, this and that. Said he’s staying at the Oasis Inn.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Did you get his name?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIA
dialogues.text: Gnaw. Sheriff Robert quickly gets up, puts on his hat and exits

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU: SARAH. Lying in Bed, like frozen. Starring into nothi In the background we hear the phone ringing.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Billy enters, picks up the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Hello?(beat) Hello? (shouting) There's no one on the other end. Billy slams down the pho

dialogues.speaker: INT. SLY WHEAT'S OFFICE, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sly, tumbler in hand, sits at his desk reviewing a file labelled NILES. The office doorbell rings. He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: SLY
dialogues.text: (muttering) Damn. I’m coming. Hold your horses. Sly crosses the room, approaches the front door and opens Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  70. SLY’S POV: There is no one at the door. SUDDENLY, a shado figure holding a revolver comes forth rapidly. BANG! BANG BANG! Three shots blast into Sly. He tumbles backwards, f onto his desk, dead before he hits the floor.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OASIS INN MOTEL, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sheriff Robert pulls into the parking lot of the motel, honking. CLYDE, the night porter, fifties, sporting thick wear, steps outside his office.

dialogues.speaker: INT. OASIS INN MOTEL, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Standing by the window of his room, Edward looks down tow the front office, watching Sheriff Robert and Clyde talki The Sheriff pulls out several sketches. Clyde points. CU: EDWARD. He cocks his gun.

dialogues.speaker: INT. / EXT. OASIS INN MOTEL, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Pistol in hand, Sheriff Robert moves up the staircase. He positions himself in front of Edward’s room, spreads his legs, both hands on the revolver. Just like in the movies knocks on the door with the tip of the barrel. No answer. CU: EDWARD. Standing to the side of the door, gun pointed Sheriff Robert pulls out the key to the motel-room. CU: DOOR LOCK. The key slides inside. The lock turns. CLI Sheriff Robert pushes the door open. It’s pitch dark insi He flips the light-switch. Nobody home. The Sheriff tip-t towards the bathroom, same procedure as at the entrance d The bathroom is empty. He carefully steps backwards, lowe his revolver and aims at the mattress in front of him. CU: EDWARD, underneath the bed, his gun pointed bulls eye the Sheriff's legs. Suddenly the SPEAKER-MICROPHONE, placed on the Sheriff Robert’s shoulder, goes off. He jumps up like he has been by lightning. It’s Earl, requesting the Sheriff. He respo with a quick “ten-four” and slowly leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU: SARAH. Lying in Bed, like frozen. Starring into nothi In the background we hear the phone ringing.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Billy enters as the phone rings again.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Hello?(beat) Oh. Hello there. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  71. INT. BELLE’S HOUSE, NIGHT In the background we see that she lives in the genteel lo middle class poverty that is the fate of most widow’s. An TV in her parlor, doilies, ancient watercolors, framed pictures everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: It’s Belle Brogden, you recall. I came and visited you and Ellen the other day.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Oh yes. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: I’m just fine and how are you?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’m just fine.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: How’s Ellen?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: She’s just swell. Uh, thanks for asking.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: I don’t mean to be any trouble, I just wondered if, about the housekeeping. ...if you needed me to look in on you?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: That’s very thoughtful of you. I'll ask Ellen and we’ll call you tomorrow. How’s that?

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: Yes, call me tomorrow then.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Ok.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: Well, good-night then.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Good night. Billy hangs up, sighs. He rubs his eyes, stops, stares ah in thought. Something’s clicked in his mind. He swiftly p out his wallet, takes out the scrap of paper with Belle’s name and address scrawled on it. BILLY (CONT’D) (muttering softly) Wait a minute. He leaves the room in a hurry. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy sits down at Niles’ desk, pulls out the old letter and places it in front of him. He takes a breath, then removes a letter from the box and compares Belle's name a address on the scrap of paper with Niles' name and addres the envelope. The handwriting is clearly the same. BELLE NILES’ LOVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy enters. Sarah appears to be sleeping. Billy leans o her and whispers.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I think we got what we needed. He kisses her. A tender moment. Sarah’s eyes slowly open.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’1l be back soon.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Be careful. Her remark surprises him.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You're worried about me?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Always. Billy kisses her once more.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Go back to sleep. He steps away, exits. CU: SARAH, cautiously listening as Billy leaves the house She jumps out of bed, grabs her jacket and leaves the roo

dialogues.speaker: INT. BARN, NIGHT
dialogues.text: The CADILLAC stands in the dark. The barn door slides ope Sarah enters. She jumps into the car turns the ignition k After a few attempts the engine starts up.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BARN, NIGHT
dialogues.text: The CADILLAC drives off into the dark, its headlights cut through the pitch black night. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  73.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SLY WHEATON'S OFFICE, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Two police cars and an ambulance are parked in the alley outside of Sly's office. Cameron’s 4x4 pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SLY WHEATON'S OFFICE, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sheriff Robert, Earl and two Officers examine the scene a POLICE PHOTOGRAPHER takes pictures. Two MEDICS are packin Sly's body. Sheriff Robert opens a file cabinet as Camero enters and surveys the scene.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Daddy was the Sheriff of this town for more than forty years and he never had one murder. I've got three murders in one week.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: And I’m sure he’d be proud of the way you're handling it. The medics pass Cameron and Sheriff Robert with Sly’s bod

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: Niles, Jamie, Sly, who's next? It's the "Dregs of Tremo Killer". The two officers and the photographer crack up.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Shut up, Earl. That ain't funny! Sheriff Robert looks around the room contemplating, tryin make some kind of connection within the puzzle of events.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The streets are empty. Billy pulls up in his convertible front of Sal's Convenience store.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SAL'S CONVENIENCE STORE, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Billy enters, as Sal nods politely. Sal takes a big swig a pint of bourbon and returns to watching TV on a small monitor. By the back door of the store, SAL'S SON and two other TEENAGERS are packing up several cases of beer. One the cases drops, muffled laughter follows. Sal peeks down hallway and spots the kids. His expression hardens.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Do you know where Laurel...

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Excuse me for a minute. Sal disappears, moments later a commotion breaks out. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  74.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You piece of shit, what’s going on here? SAL’'S SON (0.S.) I swear, I was gonna pay you back... ain’t no big deal.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No big deal? Stealing from your own father? Is that what I get for raising your ass?

dialogues.speaker: SAL'S SON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Just a couple of beers...it’s Friday night an’ all... Billy listens. He slowly moves into the narrow hallway: S is beating the living daylights out of his son.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Come on you sissy... just like your mother. Why don’t you start weeping while you're at it. Another blow hits Sal’s son hard in the face. Billy steps

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Take it easy.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? Wait at the counter and mind your own goddamn business.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Why don’t you try me?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: You're with the Niles girl, ain’t you? Yeah, I recognize you.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Motherfucker like you reminds me of my old man, until one day I walked in on him while he was screwing my girlfriend. Stuck the old service revolver right up his dirty crack and pulled the trigger. Trust me, he ain’t beating and drinking no more. Sal swings at Billy who dodges the blow, counters. Blood flying everywhere as Sal’s nose takes a bad hit. Sal’s so watches with a sense of relief and horror. Billy turns, leaves the scene. The other two teenagers, carefully move closer, checking out the carnage. Sal slowly comes to. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  75.

dialogues.speaker: SAL, (TO HIS SON)
dialogues.text: Be a man for once and take care of that son of bitch. Sal’s son gets up and the teenagers take off into the nig

dialogues.speaker: INT. OASIS INN MOTEL, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Edward is in the midst of packing his belongings. There i knock on the door. Edward grabs his gun from the night-st and moves next to the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s me, Sarah, open up. Edward checks the security-hole, opens the door. Sarah ho a Burger King paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Thought you might be hungry... I really need to use the bathroom. Edward looks at the bag. He sticks his head out into the outside hallway, checks left and right.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: You’re a strange girl...get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy walks down the street, looking at the street signs. three teenagers are on Billy's tail.

dialogues.speaker: FURTHER UP
dialogues.text: Billy stops. The teenagers stop, now about twenty yards b Billy turns around, catches them. He keeps walking, only little faster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy's brisk walk has become a slow jog and soon he is a out sprinting. The kids stay right behind. Billy rounds a corner, ducks into an alley. He gets to the end of the al only to find a high chain link fence: No way out. The teenagers round the corner and slowly move toward Billy.

dialogues.speaker: SAL'S SON
dialogues.text: Why you’re running?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Look, I don’t have any beef with you. Besides, take a look in the mirror, you don’t need another beatin’. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  76.

dialogues.speaker: SAL'S SON
dialogues.text: You think you’re some kind of badass don’t’ you, whipping my old man like a dog. Sal’s son attempts to smirk, not sure of himself. Suddenl one of the teenagers swings at Billy with a two by four. Billy quickly ducks, responds, sends the kid flying again brick wall. Out for the night.

dialogues.speaker: SAL'S SON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re gonna pay for that...

dialogues.speaker: INT. OASIS INN MOTEL, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Deep in thought, Sarah sits on the edge of the bathtub. Suddenly, we hear Edward’s voice, shouting from the bed-r

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (VO)
dialogues.text: Good thing you stopped by. You and I gotta talk. Some redneck cop was snooping around here. Gotta find myself some new digs, as in asap. Time to wrap things up. Know what I mean? (beat) What are you doing in there? Fallin’ asleep? Sarah gets up, faces the door, opens it.

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Sarah, wearing nothing but panties and bra, enters the ro She glances at Edward, steps over to the bed and slides u the covers. Edward smiles, pulls Sarah close to him.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: What’s on your mind, angel? Need some dope? Sarah starts kissing Edward, who melts away. Simultaneous she reaches out and attempts to retrieve Edward’s gun fro the night-stand. All she finds is Edward’s hand holding o firmly to his pistol. Sarah’s idea has taken an ugly turn

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is this what you’re looking for? He smiles and sticks the barrel onto Sarah’s forehead, co the gun. Sarah freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU: SWITCHBLADE-KNIFE, as the blade spring open. Sal’s son makes a quick move towards Billy. Billy grabs h arm, deflects the stab, headbutts Sal’s son hard. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  77. Sal’s son drops the blade, goes down on his knees, holdin his bloody face. The third kid freezes, then takes off running. CU: Billy, breathing hard.

dialogues.speaker: INT. OASIS INN MOTEL, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Edward forces himself on top of Sarah, about to rape her again. Desperate, she reaches out and slowly, inch by inc pulls her jeans jacket closer. Edward is too caught up to notice as Sarah’s fingers frantically search the pockets. Finally, she removes a disposable syringe. In one bold move, she jolts upward and sticks the needle Edward's left eye. Edward drops his gun as he covers his with both hands. Howling with pain, he violently jerks backwards, attempting to remove the syringe. Sarah picks the pistol, points it at Edward. She paces in front of hi Her voice trembles with fear, anger, anxiety.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Eddie... did you know you’ve got the smallest penis I’ve ever seen. All the time you were on top me... nope, didn’t feel a thing. Nothing. Zero. I kept thinking: Poor Eddie. What a sad story. You know, I almost started calling you two inch Eddie. Kinda funny, no? Edward is shrieking. Lots of blood is oozing from his eye

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I cried plenty. I did. The mere thought of you touching me... I couldn’t get it out of my head... But look who’s crying now? You want me to end your misery? No Problem! Sarah fires one round into Edward’s chest. His remaining opens wide as his body slips away into oblivion. She slow lowers the gun, stares at the corpse. She’s never shot anybody before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy sees a street sign: LAUREL STREET. He takes out Bel scrap of paper, starts looking at the numbers on the hous

dialogues.speaker: INT. OASIS INN MOTEL, NIGHT
dialogues.text: A series of quick cuts: Sarah, towel in hand, is busy wiping off her fingerprints inside the bathroom. In the living-room she starts removi the bloody sheets. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  78. At the entrance we see Edward covered from head to toe in bloody bed-sheet - hunched over in an arm chair. An exten cord is wrapped around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy crosses a side street and looks to his right. CU: Billy. His face drops as he spots Niles’ Cadillac par in the back of the Oasis Inn Motel. Under great distress Sarah manages to drag Edward across room toward a french window. She pulls the curtains, open the narrow, floor to ceiling double windows and peeks ove the railing of a small, two feet wide balcony. The CADILL below is parked with its trunk towards the building. CU: BILLY, hiding near the rear of the motel, watching Sa standing on the balcony. Sarah pulls out the keys and hits a small remote attached the key-chain. The CADILLAC’S trunk pops open. She takes a deep breath and picks up the heavy load. She Manages to push Edward upright against the railing, then grabs his ankles and pulls. Just like a pendulum, Edward' own weight draws him over the railing, facing the trunk below. One last shove and Edward's is flying. CRASH: Edward miss the trunk. His body lands on a row of large bushes instea CU: BILLY. Staring, amazed. Sarah, large laundry bag in hand, comes hurrying down the back staircase. She throws the plastic bag into the corne the Cadillac’s trunk, then rushes over to Edward. With al her remaining strength left, she grabs him by his arms an starts tugging. Soon, the ordeal is over. Edward is stash away. Sarah slams the trunk hood shut, jumps into the fro seat and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TREMO STREET CORNER, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Billy turns back onto Laurel Street... CU: SAL’S SON, swinging a baseball-bat... WHACK...connecting with Billy's face. Billy goes down as three kids hit and kick him. Once exhausted, the teenager run away, howling, laughing as they go. Across the street an older two-story house, the porch-lights go on, a windo opens.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy is lying on a small couch in Belle's tiny living ro His face is covered with dried blood, a bag of ice sits o his forehead. Belle helps Billy to sip from a small flask His expression sours as he swallows the liquid.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: You had yourself a little trouble?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I had these three guys following me... Billy looks across the room: Its Sheriff Robert. The Sher pulls out Edward’s police drawing, approaches Billy.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Take a look. Buddy of your's?

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: Leave the poor boy alone. He's been beaten.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: He’1l live. Come on now, son. You might as well come clean. Billy peeks at the sketch, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You tell me. Who the hell is he?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: He's the guy who stole the El Camino. Probably the same son of a bitch you sent to kill Niles. Belle is shocked.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: Stop it, Robert. No one killed Mr. Niles.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You're insane. I’ve never seen that guy in my life. Billy's head spins, as he drops back onto the couch.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: Bob, leave it be. Reluctantly, Sheriff Robert crosses toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Call me if there’s any more trouble, Mama. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  80. Billy's eyes open wide. His attention is caught by two se of photographs. One is with Belle, her two sons and her husband the Sheriff, Robert Sr. The other is a picture of with Zachary Niles.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You know, I was looking for you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: For me? If it was about the house-keeping it could’ve waited till tomorrow. Billy rises, a little fragile and goes back to the pictur

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: No, it wasn’t about the housekeeping... you and your late husband raised two sons, Sheriff Bob and Cameron.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: Yes, that’s right. Two big beautiful boys.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Your family didn’t mind all those long hours with you keeping house for Zachary Niles.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: It was a privilege working for an accomplished and prosperous man like Mr. Niles. And we needed the extra money. Billy peers at the photos again.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You, the late Sheriff and Bob, you look like three peas in a pod.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Not Cameron though. Belle shrugs a little uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you mean. She adds a nervous smile that doesn’t convince.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You truly admired and respected Niles, didn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: Well of course, I told you that’s why... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  81.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You had a child with him didn’t you... Belle’s eyes darken in alarm.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: Wha... How dare you...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I read the letters you wrote to him, asking that he acknowledge your son. How could you stand for it... what he did to you? I mean after the way you took care of him and the way you felt about him?

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: (beat) It wasn’t that simple. What would people think if they knew what we were up to? How would they treat my family, my husband, my little boys...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: If you didn’t want to make him pay, there was somebody else who did.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Cameron is Niles’ son. And when Niles handed the inheritance to Ellen, he realized that he was going to be cut out of everything that was rightly his. Cut out, same as his mother had been.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: You have no right...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Deep down you gotta know... that it was Cameron that killed Niles.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: That’s not possible... Zachary... Mr. Niles’ death was an accident...

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You’re not up on current affairs ma’am. The coroner’s ruled Niles’ death a homicide. (a beat) Your son killed his own father. Belle stares at Billy. A look of horror covers her face.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: Get out of here. You-you--GET OUT! Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  82. She starts to sob hysterically on the edge of violence. BELLE (CONT’D) I said LEAVE! Billy, a little rickety on his feet, exits. Belle, sniffl watches through a blind to make sure that he’s gone. She to the phone. Dials. BELLE (CONT’D) Bobby? It’s your Ma. I hate to be a bother, but it’s important.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAMERON'S OFFICE, NIGHT
dialogues.text: A match ignites as Cameron lights up a gas fireplace insi his office. He crosses towards a large drawer and pulls o file marked "Niles". Its the same file we saw earlier at Wheaton’s office. We see a second file open to Billy's po sheet, pictures of Billy and Sarah as well as a copy of a newspaper clipping: "DEAD JANE DOE IS ELLEN NILES 21, DAUGHTER OF FAMED ATTORNEY", is highlighted in bright yel Cameron moves back to the fireplace and tosses all docume one by one, into the flames. He curiously looks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Robert removes several sheets from a fax machine. sits down at his desk, unrolls the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy sits inside the convertible, contemplating. Moments later he steps out of the car, staggers toward the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy stands in the doorway and takes in the sights and.. smells. The room is dark but light flows in from the kitc Sarah is cooking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah turns, startled by Billy, who's standing in the doorway. He looks awful. Considering Sarah’s previous ord she appears to be in control of herself.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Ran into a couple of local tough guys. Sarah steps up to Billy, looks at his face.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Jes... that doesn’t look very good. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy sits on the edge of the bathtub while Sarah careful cleans his face.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: So what’d you do all night?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I went shopping. I found another market a couple of miles outside of town. Hold still. Sarah applies a band-aide onto Billy’s forehead, then kis him.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There you go. Just like new.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Thanks. How did you get around? Sarah hesitates, then looks at Billy point blank.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: How did I get around? I took the Cadillac if that’s ok with you. Dinner will be ready in a minute. She smiles and exits the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sporting a new set of clothes, Billy has cleaned himself He walks into the kitchen and starts searching the cabine He pulls out a bottle of Jack Daniels, then opens the refrigerator, tosses a couple of ice cubes into a glass. is about to close the refrigerator when he notices the sh of a gun underneath a kitchen towel. He peeks into the li room where Sarah is busy setting up the table. Billy take out the familiar pistol, tucks it into the back of his pa Shortly after Sarah enters. Puzzled, she looks at Billy, he pours himself a stiff one. He points to the stove.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Looks great. Billy takes a big swig from his tumbler, frowns.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Boy, I really needed that. Billy smiles at Sarah as he leaves the kitchen, carrying bottle of Jack Daniels with him. Sarah freezes. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah and Billy sit at the candle lit table. Sarah looks as Billy is picking his food, preoccupied.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I forgot the salad.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Sarah moves to the refrigerator, opens it and takes out a large bowl.

dialogues.speaker: DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Billy watches Sarah serve. He pours himself another round this time he fills the glass to the brim, drinks up. Sara shocked, hands shaking, sits down.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: There were all these cook books in the kitchen. This dish is a local favorite.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Very good. Billy makes no effort to conceal the fact that any small is of zero interest to him.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: This morning, I was thinking about Stanley's, the day you asked me out. I remember coming out of the kitchen with your turkey-sandwich but you had left already. I thought I would never see you again. (beat) And here we are. You and I. Having dinner. Billy looks straight at Sarah, continuing his silence.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-Stanley’s. I hope I’1ll never have to work in a place like that again.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Why should you? You’re going to be rich very soon. Aware that Billy is not quite himself, Sarah is getting increasingly nervous. She lights up a cigarette, as Billy takes another swig from his glass. Finally, Sarah finds t courage to ask:

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: What’s up with the drinking? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  85.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I’m a bit on edge. That’s all. Billy finishes the tumbler, puts the glass down and cross the room. He picks up the phone, dials. A new intensity o purpose in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAMERON'S OFFICE, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Cameron picks up the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Billy? How’re you doing?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Well, I guess you could say, I’ve been better and I’ve been worse.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I know the feeling. What’s on your mind Billy? Periodically Billy’s glance meets Sarah's.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: The headline is that I know a lot about you, your brother, your mother, and Niles.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Billy, you gave me the wrong tape.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You know, I wonder what would happen if brother Bob gets a hold of the video? What do you think he’d say?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I don’t think you trying to blackmail me and besmirch the late Zachary Niles’ spotless reputation is going to put you in good with the Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: ..."Zachary Niles’ spotless reputation”. What the fuck is wrong with you? Listen, you want me to call the Sheriff right fucking now? There’s a long silence. BILLY (CONT’D) I’m gonna take that as a “no.” Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  86.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: How much do you want, Billy? Five thousand?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Make it ten. Cash. Tonight. Then we’1l get out of here, so that you and the rest of the cracker assholes can stew in your own shit.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (Pause) Okay. The phone goes dead. Billy takes his seat at the table.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: The lawyer? It’s not coming through is it? The inheritance.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Nope. That’s one number that’s never comin’ up. He plays with his food. Sarah is about to break.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I had enough. I wanna get out of here, Billy. As in yesterday. Billy says nothing, then he just stares at her coldly.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s wrong? What’s going on? She gets up, starts pacing the room. Billy remains seated

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What’s going on? Well, I think I should be asking questions. (Pause) Like, what do you have in mind for after dinner? Stuff me in the trunk with, you know, what's his name...? Billy pulls out Edwards cash checking card, reads: BILLY (CONT’D) Edward Romero. That’s it. He throws the card in front of Sarah’s plate. BILLY (CONT’D) What? You don’t think I know where you score your dope from? I saw you at the motel tonight. Boy, what a spectacle. Tell me Sarah, did you fuck him first and then kill him...how exactly did it go down? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Sarah is shocked. She hesitates, then:

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I did not fuck him! That guy is Ellen's dealer. She owed him a ton of money and somehow he thinks that I have to pay him back.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Well, he’s dead now, isn’t he? Might as well get rid of me while you’re at it, no? I mean, that is the plan after all isn’t it? Why split all that cash with him, or me, right? Sarah is stunned by this.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: How dare you? I didn’t have a clue about Ellen’s money till I found that letter. Besides, this is all your scheme! Not mine! Remember?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: So, you're telling me that “Edward Romero” didn’t have the same idea, a whole lot earlier?... I should had seen it coming, but I gotta hand it to you. I bought you hook-line and sinker. She walks over to him and coolly slaps him in the face. B wipes the slap off his cheek. He stands his ground. BILLY (CONT’D) So, what’s next? You’re gonna go up- stairs, shoot up some dope... then a little later you'll sit close, maybe even blow me while you’re at it and when I’m all moonstruck you’re gonna put a bullet between my eyes? Well, there is going to be a slight change in plans. The poise Sarah showed in slapping Billy has worn itself She starts to crack, trembles with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You’re drunk. That’s why you talk so crazy! You think I went to that hotel room to get high, or worse, sleep with that animal? You think I fooled you. You fooled me. I didn’t know you were just another asshole. Billy stands up, pulls out the gun and points it at Sarah Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  88.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Maybe I am drunk. But I’m not stupid. Tell me what’s the gun doing in the fridge? Desert? Sarah's face drops. She slowly backs up and starts to cry then turns and rushes upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cameron exits his office as Sheriff Robert pulls up in hi cruiser and honks. Cameron steps up to the car, slides in

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: I just got back from Mama’s. Guess who was there? The boyfriend. Billy.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: What'd he want?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Mama found him in the street. Got a little roughed up. Suits him well, that smart ass. Anyway, I got a piece of news for you that’s gonna knock your socks off. Sheriff Robert pulls out several fax sheets, including a of Billy’s police file.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ellen Niles is dead.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: What? Who are...

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Sarah Johnson, Ellen’s roommate and Billy Brody, Sarah Johnson's boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: No! Where did you get this?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: A good pal from the LA Police Department xeroxed me the whole skinny on them two. Says Ellen had fallen in with the wrong crowd after her parents accident. She overdosed on heroin weeks ago. And this Brody guy, he did time in jail for forgery, illegal gambling. It’s all there.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: (reading) I can't believe it. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  89.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Not to say I told you so, but I knew something was up with them two. I’m gonna round up my boys first thing in the morning and arrest them punks. Cameron takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Good thinking... Bob, we've got another problem. I can barely talk about this... Cameron hands Sheriff Robert an envelope. The Sheriff ope it, takes out Belle's letter.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Him... Brody, whatever his name... gave it to me. They found it in the house... it's horrible... Sheriff Robert starts reading the letter.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: What the hell is this? Niles didn't have no son. It's a forgery.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Look at the writing. You know who's writing that is. Sheriff Robert looks as if he is getting punched in the g

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: I don't know nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Mama used to spend a lot of time over there.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: +». don't say it.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I'm that son!

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: You better shut up.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Ask herself if you don’t believe your own brother. This whole thing is just awful. Sheriff Robert is breathing hard. After a long silence: CAMERON (CONT’D) Bob, I’m just as shocked as you are, but I’m sure Mama will straighten all this out.(Pause) Take it easy. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  90. Cameron slides out of the car. Sheriff Robert turns the engine, pulls out. Cameron looks on as the police cruiser takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah has locked herself into the bathroom. Her face is covered in tears. Billy is standing outside in the hallwa

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Sarah. Open up... Sarah reaches inside her jeans-jacket. She pulls out seve bullets and slides them underneath the bathroom door, int the hallway. Billy eyes widen. He picks up one of the bullets, then checks the chamber of the pistol: It’s empt

dialogues.speaker: BILLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shit. Sarah... I...just uhm... about the gun. There’s no bullets in the chamber...

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Stay away! Nothing worse than the stench of booze. There is a long pause. Nobody knows what to say. Then:

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, my dad owned this car dealership. When sales were up and he was drunk enough, he’d run around the house calling himself the ‘King of Chrysler’. It was so damn stupid. On weekends he had these business friends over to our house. His “Inner Circle” he said. Sometimes, around three, four in the morning, he would come bashing into our rooms and drag us down into the den. First they made us drink and sometimes we had to dance and strip. Billy glances at the bullets as he listens closely.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dad came up with this idea for a contest. Whoever was the most sexy was allowed to go back to bed. I was eight, I think. My two sisters were older and they’d do all kinds of things. I tell you, the stink of liquor and old men, I’1l1 never forget it.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: I was wrong. I’m... I’m sorry. I mean it. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  91.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Listen. Eddie showed up out of the blue. I was going to tell you, I swear, but he kept saying that he was going to kill us both if I mention him to anybody. There is silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: We're getting outta here first thing in the morning. Billy turns and heads downstairs. Sarah slowly rises from floor, picks up a ‘loaded’ syringe from the bathtubs edge She points the needle towards the sink and squeezes the b liquid down the drain until the plastic is empty.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PORCH OF BELLE'S HOUSE, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Belle is seated on a rickety porch swing. She speaks slow on the verge of tears, while confessing to Sheriff Robert is in utter disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: My life ain’t nothing but lies.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: I never wanted you to find out. Sheriff Robert Sr. raised both of you, but you’re his only true son. I'm sorry, but I thought it was for your own good.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: A life built on lies and the only people I've ever trusted... perpetrators. Who gets the inheritance? Cameron?

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: Don’t mention that at a time like this! After all those crazy mean things that boy said you gotta promise me you won’t arrest your brother, your own flesh and blood?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: I ain’t no attorney like my “brother” Cameron...but trust me, I’m gettin’ to the bottom of this and see what’s what.

dialogues.speaker: BELLE
dialogues.text: Robert please. Your brother didn’t know! Upset the Sheriff exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy sits at the dining table, a video tape is placed ne to the familiar letter-box. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  92. The old record player from Niles’ bedroom has been moved the living-room. Classical music reverberates through the warm, humid night.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DRIVEWAY OF NILES ESTATE, NIGHT
dialogues.text: A car, headlights shut off, approaches the estate. The ca comes to a stop. The driver’s door slowly opens. CU: BOOTS, as somebody walks about the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: INT. POLICE CAR, NIGHT
dialogues.text: The police car is parked outside Joe’s diner. Sheriff Rob sits behind the wheel, silent. Earl is sitting next to hi His sixth sense tells him that something is wrong: Finall

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: You know that stuff causes mouth cancer?

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: I ain't worried. My dad's been chewing for over forty years. Ain't nothing ever happen to him. Sheriff Robert shakes his head. He hands Earl the fax.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: The girl at the house is an impersonator. And that Billy fella has a list of priors as long as the eye can see.

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: You was right all along, boos. It’1ll be like shootin’ deer in a pen. Early studies the fax, then turns toward the Sheriff and holds up a monogrammed belt buckle displaying a big "C".

dialogues.speaker: EARL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Before I forget. Isn't this your brother's?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF ROBERT
dialogues.text: Where did you get that?

dialogues.speaker: EARL
dialogues.text: At Jamie's cabin. I was out in the woods yesterday, finishing up the report. I just happened to take a closer look and there it was. Right underneath the bed. Sheriff Robert stares at Earl. Something clicks. The Sher turns the ignition, floors the gas-pedal. Earl spits a hu wad of tobacco out the window, reaches into the back seat retrieves a shotgun. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  93.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DRIVEWAY TO NILES ESTATE, NIGHT
dialogues.text: We PULL OUT revealing Cameron, walking towards the house. INT. NILES’ MANSION, NIGHT The front door slowly opens. Cameron enters. Billy, still the table, turns around and sees Cameron’s silhouette.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Mr. Brogden?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: You must be crazy to still be here.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Did you bring the money?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: You got the tape? Billy taps with his index finger on the videotape placed to him. Cameron crosses the room pulls out a manila envel and slides it across the large dining table. Billy picks the envelope looks inside: Bundles of cash. He pockets th envelope, then shoves the tape towards Cameron. CAMERON (CONT’D) I hope this is what I came for?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You know, the guy in the black mask was kind of extra spooky. He looked to be your size and weight.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: We'll discuss your tastes in home video entertainment on some other occasion... Cameron quickly stashes the tape into his jacket. CAMERON (CONT’D) I hope you can spend that ten thousand before they arrest you.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: It was you that killed Niles.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: The world is a better place with Niles absent from it, trust me on that.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: And I bet you knew about us all along? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  94.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: Well, I figured it out pretty quickly. I’'d happened to come across this article about Ellen’s parents’ accident. Next thing I know, you kids show up here with your hands out, well, it didn’t exactly look legitimate. You two had everybody in town all worked up. Kept any kind of suspicion away from me. Perfect timing. Cameron starts to back away.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hung around this dead-end shithole for twenty years. The inheritance is my ticket out. I sweated for it and I will have it. But, hell, I tried to be fair to you. I gave you and that chippie of yours every chance to run... but now... you're going to jail for murder.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You can't prove I killed the old man, ‘cause I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: No, they got enough evidence that Jamie Albright killed him.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Who’s he?

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: The young fellow who tried to retrieve the video.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You can't link me to... one of your boyfriends.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: I don’t know. The police is going to find your driver's license about three feet from where good old Jamie was killed. I called you from his cabin several times, so it's going to look like...well, you've been in contact for... quite a while.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Keep dreaming. You’re not going to see a single dime of Niles’ money: Sly Wheaton has a legal document proving that every cent of the estate was intended for Ellen and nobody else. Period.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON
dialogues.text: You know, Billy. You’ve got balls but no brains. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  95.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sly Wheaton had an unfortunate setback tonight. Trust me, he won’t be processing any more documents. Legal or otherwise. Cameron lets this sink in. Game over. The music in the background comes to an end.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERON, (CONT'D)
